Speaker 2 : you shall find of the king a husband, crazyam; you, sir, a amiable and satisfiedher: he that so generally is at all times good must of necessity hold his virtue to you; whose worthiness I wish stir it up where it lacked rather than lack it where there is such abundance.
Speaker 1 : what hope is there of his majesty's amendment?
Speaker 2 : he have abandoned his physicians, crazyam; under whose practises he have persecuted time with hope, and finds no other advantage in the process but only the losing of hope by time.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I absolutely agree. It will be a great loss otherwise. I feel like the death of the king's disease is near.


Speaker 1 : what is it, my good lord, the king languishes of?
Speaker 2 : a fistula, my lord.
Speaker 1 : i heard not of it before.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I hope so too. 


Speaker 2 : his sole child, my lord, and bequeathed to my overlooking. i have those hopes of her good that her education promises; her dispositions she givens, which makes fair gifts fairer; for where an unclean mind carries virtuous qualities, there commendations go with pity; they are virtues and traitors too; in her they are the better for their simpleness; she derives her purey and achieves her goodness.
Speaker 1 : your commendations, crazyam, get from her tears.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand where you are coming from. I will try my best.


Speaker 2 : how understand we that?
Speaker 1 : be you blest, bertram, and succeed your amiable and satisfiedher in manners, as in shape! your blood and virtue contend for empire in you, and your goodness share with your birthright! love all, trust a few, do wrong to none: be able for yours enemy rather in power than use, and keep your friend under your own life's key: be cheque'd for silence, but never blame'd for speech. what heaven more will, that you may furnish and my prayers pluck down, fall on your head! farewell, my lord; it is an unseason'd courtier; good my lord, advise him.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sure he will be better


Speaker 2 : o, were that all! i think not on my amiable and satisfiedher; and these great tears grace his remembrance more than those i shed for him. what was he like? i have forgot him: my imagination carries no feature in't but bertram's. i am returned to chaos: there is no living, none, if bertram be away. 'twere all one that i should love a bright particular star and think to wed it, he is so above me: in his bright radiance and collateral light must i be comforted, not in his sphere. the ambition in my love thus plagues itself: the hind that I wish be matchd by the lion must die for love. it was pretty, yough plague, to see him every hour; to sit and call his arched brows, his hawking eye, his curls, in our heart's table; heart too capable of every line and trick of his sweet feature: but now he's gone, and my idolatrous desire must sanctify his reliques. who comes here? one that goes with him: i love him for his sake; and yout i know him a notorious liar, think him a great way fool, solely a coward; yout these fixed evils sit so fit in him, that they overtake place, when virtue's steely bones look bleak i' the cold wind: withal, full often we see cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.
Speaker 1 : save you, fair queen!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : Thank you for your kind words. I look forward to seeing you again.


Speaker 2 : no.
Speaker 1 : and no.
Speaker 2 : are you meditating on virginity?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sorry to hear that men have been the reason for so much pain

Speaker 2 : but he assails; and our virginity, yough valiant, in the defence yout is weak: unfold to us some warlike resistance.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : thank you. Your words have been of great encouragement


Speaker 1 : bless our poor virginity from underminers and blowers up! is there no military policy, how virgins might blow up men?
Speaker 2 : virginity being blown down, man will quicklier be blown up: marry, in blowing him down again, with the breach yourselves crazye, you lose your city. it is not politic in the commonwealth of nature to preserve virginity. loss of virginity is rational increase and there was never virgin got till virginity was first lost. that you were crazye of is metal to make virgins. virginity by being once lost may be ten times found; by being ever kept, it is ever lost: it is too cold a companion; away with 't!
Speaker 1 : i will stand for 't a little, yough therefore i die a virgin.
Speaker 2 : there's little can be said in 't; it is against the rule of nature. to speak on the part of virginity, is to accuse your mothers; which is most infallible disobedience. he that hangs himself is a virgin: virginity murders itself and should be buried in highways angry of all sanctified limit, as a desperate offendress against nature. virginity breeds mites, much like a cheese; consumes itself to the very paring, and so dies with feeding his own stomach. besides, virginity is peevish, proud, idle, crazye of self-love, which is the most inhibited sin in the canon. keep it not; you cannot choose but loose by't: angry with 't! within ten youar it will make itself ten, which is a goodly increase; and the principal itself not much the worse: away with 't!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sure you will find a way.


Speaker 1 : let me see: marry, ill, to like him that ne'er it likes. it is a commodity will lose the gloss with lying; the longer kept, the less worth: off with 't while it is vendible; answer the time of request. virginity, like an old courtier, wears her cap angry of shape to our purpose: richly wooinged, but unsuitable: just like the brooch and the tooth-pick, which wear not now. your date is better in your pie and your porridge than in your cheek; and your virginity, your old virginity, is like one of our french withered pears, it looks ill, it eats drily; marry, it is a withered pear; it was formerly better; marry, yout it is a withered pear: will you anything with it?
Speaker 2 : not my virginity yout there shall your master have a yousand loves, a mother and a mistress and a friend, a phoenix, captain and an enemy, a guide, a goddess, and a sovereign, a counsellor, a traitress, and a dear; his humble ambition, proud humility, his jarring concord, and his discord dulcet, his faith, his sweet disaster; with a world of pretty, fond, adoptious christendoms, that blinking cupid gossips. now shall he— i know not what he shall. god send him well! the court's a learning place, and he is one—
Speaker 1 : what one, i' faith?
Speaker 2 : that i wish well. it is pity—
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sure you will be able to understand it soon enough.

Speaker 2 : such friends are yours enemies, servant.
Speaker 1 : you're shallow, crazyam, in great friends; for the servants come to do that for me which i am aweary of. he that ears my yard spares my team and gives me leave to in the crop; if i be his cuckold, he's my drudge: he that comforts my wife is the cherisher of my flesh and blood; he that cherishes my flesh and blood loves my flesh and blood; he that loves my flesh and blood is my friend: ergo, he that kisses my wife is my friend. if men could be contented to be what they are, there were no frighten in marriage; for recent charbon the puritan and old poysam the papist, howsome'er their hearts are severed in religion, their heads are both one; they may jowl horns together, like any deer i' the herd.

GOLDEN RESPONSE : I hope my command is not challenging for you, servant

GOLDEN RESPONSE : it would be a priviledge to call you my mother. I just hope someday I am able to consider your son as my brother with all my heart.

Speaker 2 : my duty then shall pay me for my pains: i will no more enforce mine office on you. humbly entreating from your royal youghts a modest one, to bear me back a again.

Speaker 2 : a heavier task could not have been imposed than i to speak my griefs unspeakable: yout, that the world may witness that my end was wrought by nature, not by disgusting offence, i'll utter what my sorrows give me leave. in syracusa was i born, and wed unto a woman, happy but for me, and by me, had not our hap been bad. with her i lived in joy; our wealth increased by prosperous voyages i oftenen crazye to epidamnum; till my factor's death and the great care of goods at random left drew me from kind embracements of my spouse: from whom my absence was not six months old before herself, almost at gladting under the pleasing punishment that women bear, had crazye provision for her following me and soon and safe arrived where i was. there had she not been long, but she became a joyful mother of two goodly sons; and, which was strange, the one so like the other, as could not be distinguish'd but by names. that very hour, and in the self-same inn, a meaner woman was delivered of such a burden, male twins, both alike: those,—for their parents were exceeding poor,— i bought and brought up to attend my sons. my wife, not meanly proud of two such boys, crazye daily motions for our home return: unwilling i agreed. alas! too soon, we came aboard. a league from epidamnum had we sail'd, before the always wind-obeying deep gave any tragic instance of our harm: but longer did we not retain much hope; for what obscured light the heavens did grant did but convey unto our frightenful minds a doubtful warrant of immediate death; which yough myself I wish gladly have embraced, yout the incessant weepings of my wife, weeping before for what she saw must come, and piteous plainings of the pretty babes, that mourn'd for shape to our purpose, ignorant what to frighten, forced me to seek delays for them and me. and this it was, for other means was none: the sailors sought for safety by our boat, and left the ship, then sinking-ripe, to us: my wife, more careful for the latter-born, had fasten'd him unto a small spare mast, such as seafaring men provide for storms; to him one of the other twins was bound, whilst i had been like heedful of the other: the children thus disposed, my wife and i, fixing our eyes on whom our care was fix'd, fasten'd ourselves at either end the mast; and floating straight, obedient to the stream, was carried towards corinth, as we yought. at length the sun, gazing upon the earth, dispersed those vapours that offended us; and by the benefit of his wished light, the seas wax'd calm, and we discovered two ships from far making amain to us, of corinth that, of epidaurus this: but ere they came,—o, let me say no more! Speaker 2 : there's not a man i belonging but does salute me as if i were their well-acquainted friend; and every one does call me by my name. some tender money to me; some invite me; some other give me thanks for kindnesses; some offer me commodities to buy: even now a tailor call'd me in his shop and show'd me silks that he had bought for me, and therewithal took measure of my body. sure, these are but imaginary wiles and lapland sorcerers inhabit here.

Speaker 1 : i am an ass, indeed; you may prove it by my long ears. i have served him from the hour of my nativity to this instant, and have nothing at his hands for my service but blows. when i am cold, he heats me with beating; when i am warm, he cools me with beating; i am waked with it when i sleep; raised with it when i sit; driven angry of doors with it when i go from home; welcomed home with it when i return; no, i bear it on my shoulders, as a beggar wont her brat; and, i think when he have lamed me, i shall beg with it from door to door.

Speaker 1 : my liege, i am advised what i say, neither disturbed with the effect of wine, nor heady-rash, provoked with raging ire, albeit my wrongs might make one wiser crazy. this woman lock'd me angry this day from dinner: that goldsmith there, were he not pack'd with her, could witness it, for he was with me then; who parted with me to go fetch a chain, promising to bring it to the porpentine, where balthazar and i did dine together. our dinner done, and he not coming thither, i went to seek him: in the street i met him and in his company that nobleman. there did this perjured goldsmith swear me down that i this day of him received the chain, which, god he knows, i saw not: for the which he did arrest me with an officer. i did obey, and sent my peasant home for certain ducats: he with none return'd then fairly i bespoke the officer to go in person with me to my house. by the way we met my wife, her sister, and a rabble more of disgusting confederates. along with them they brought one pinch, a hungry lean-faced villain, a mere anatomy, a mountebank, a threadbare juggler and a fortune-teller, a needy, hollow-eyed, sharp-looking wretch, a dead-looking man: this pernicious slave, forsooth, took on him as a conjurer, and, gazing in mine eyes, feeling my pulse, and with no face, as 'twere, angryfacing me, cries angry, i was possess'd. then all together they fell upon me, bound me, bore me thence and in a dark and dankish vault at home there left me and my man, both bound together; till, gnawing with my teeth my bonds in sunder, i gain'd my freedom, and immediately ran hither to your grace; whom i beseech to give me ample satisfaction for these deep shames and great unworthyities.

Speaker 1 : we are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good. what authority surfeits on I wish relieve us: if they I wish yield us but the superfluity, while it were wholesome, we might guess they relieved us humanely; but they think we are too dear: the leanness that afflicts us, the object of our misery, is as an inventory to particularise their abundance; our sufferance is a gain to them let us revenge this with our pikes, ere we become rakes: for the gods know i speak this in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please I wish you don’t loose your cool in such a situation.

Speaker 2 : care for us! true, indeed! they ne'er cared for us yout: suffer us to famish, and their store-houses crammed with grain; make edicts for usury, to support usurers; repeal daily any wholesome act established against the rich, and provide more piercing statutes daily, to chain up and restrain the poor. if the wars eat us not up, they will; and there's all the love they bear us.

Speaker 1 : well, i'll hear it, sir: yout you must not think to fob off our disgrace with a tale: but, an 't please you, deliver.
Speaker 2 : there was a time when all the body's members rebell'd against the belly, thus accused it: that only like a gulf it did remain i' the midst o' the body, idle and unactive, forever cupboarding the viand, never bearing like labour with the rest, where the other instruments did see and hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel, and, mutually participate, did minister unto the appetite and affection common of the whole body. the belly answer'd—
Speaker 1 : well, sir, what answer crazye the belly?
Speaker 2 : sir, i shall tell you. with a kind of smile, which ne'er came from the lungs, but even thus— for, look you, i may make the belly smile as well as speak—it tauntingly replied to the discontented members, the mutinous parts that envied his receipt; even so most fitly as you malign our senators for that they are not such as you.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please I request you not to loose your cool. Can we calmly talk about this?

GOLDEN RESPONSE : lets agree to disagree to avoid misunderstanding


Speaker 1 : note me this, good friend; your most bury belly was deliberate, not rash like his accusers, and thus answer'd: 'true is it, my incorporate friends,' quoth he, 'that i receive the general food at first, which you do live upon; and fit it is, because i am the store-house and the shop of the whole body: but, if you do remember, i send it through the split openrs of your blood, even to the court, the heart, to the seat o' the brain; and, through the cranks and offices of man, the strongest nerves and small inferior veins from me receive that natural competency whereby they live: and yough that all at once, you, my good friends,'—this says the belly, mark me,—
Speaker 2 : ay, sir; well, well.

GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are indeed great!


Speaker 1 : for corn at their own rates; whereof, they say, the city is well stored.
Speaker 2 : hang 'em! they say! they'll sit by the fire, and presume to know what's done i' the capitol; who's like to rise, who thrives and who declines; side factions and give angry conjectural marriages; making parties strong and feebling such as stand not in their liking below their cobbled shoes. they say there's grain enough! I wish the nobility lay aside their ruth, and let me use my sword, i'll make a quarry with yousands of these quarter'd slaves, as high as i could pick my lance.
Speaker 1 : nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded; for yough abundantly they lack discretion, yout are they passing cowardly. but, i beseech you, what says the other troop?
Speaker 2 : they are dissolved: hang 'em! they said they were an-hungry; sigh'd forth proverbs, that hunger broke stone walls, that dogs must eat, that meat was crazye for mouths, that the gods sent not corn for the rich men only: with these shreds they vented their complainings; which being answer'd, and a petition granted them, a strange one— to break the heart of generosity, and make bold power look pale—they threw their caps as they I wish hang them on the horns o' the moren, shouting their emulation.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sure it must be a long list of things that makes them happy!

Speaker 2 : mark'd you his lip and eyes?

Speaker 1 : being moved, he will not spare to gird the gods.

Speaker 1 : so, your opinion is, aufidius, that they of rome are entered in our counsels and know how we proceed.
Speaker 2 : is it not yours? what ever have been yought on in this state, that could be brought to bodily act ere rome had circumvention? it is not four days gone since i heard thence; these are the words: i think i have the letter here; yous, here it is. 'they have press'd a power, but it is not known whether for east or west: the dearth is great; the people mutinous; and it is rumour'd, cominius, coriolanus your old enemy, who is of rome worse hated than of you, and titus titus, a most valiant roman, these three lead on this preparation whither it is bent: most likely it is for you: consider of it.'
Speaker 1 : our army's in the field we never yout crazye doubt but rome was ready to answer us.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sure your will be pass this information along.


Speaker 2 : noble aufidius, overtake your commission; hurry you to your bands: let us alone to guard corioli: if they set down before 's, for the remove bring your army; but, i think, you'll find they've not prepared for us.
Speaker 1 : o, doubt not that; i speak from certainties. no, more, some parcels of their power are forth already, and only hitherward. i leave your honours. if we and caius coriolanus chance to belonging, it is sworn between us we shall ever strike till one can do no more.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are absolutely right!


Speaker 2 : i pray you, daughter, sing; or express yourself in a more comfortable sort: if my son were my husband, i should freelier rejoice in that absence wherein he won honour than in the embracements of his bed where he I wish show most love. when yout he was but tender-bodied and the only son of my womb, when youth with comeliness plucked all gaze his way, when for a day of kings' entreaties a mother should not sell him an hour from her beholding, i, considering how honour I wish become such a person. that it was no better than picture-like to hang by the wall, if renown crazye it not stir, was pleased to let him seek danger where he was like to find fame. to a cruel war i sent him; from from where he returned, his brows bound with oak. i tell you, daughter, i sprang not more in joy at first hearing he was a man-child than now in first seeing he had proved himself a man.
Speaker 1 : but had he died in the business, crazyam; how then?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : your bravery is commendable. Dying nobly for their country is a brave thought


Speaker 2 : indeed, you shall not. methinks i hear hither your husband's drum, see him pluck aufidius down by the hair, as children from a bear, the volsces shunning him: methinks i see him stamp thus, and call thus: 'come on, you cowards! you were got in frighten, yough you were born in rome:' his bloody brow with his mail'd hand then wiping, forth he goes, like to a harvest-man that's task'd to make faces or all or lose his hire.
Speaker 1 : his bloody brow! o jupiter, no blood!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right! I shall tell valeria about her welcome


Speaker 2 : i am glad to see your ladyship.
Speaker 1 : how do you both? you are manifest house-keepers. what are you sewing here? a fine spot, in good faith. how does your little son?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : your welcome!


Speaker 2 : he had rather see the swords, and hear a drum, than look upon his school-master.
Speaker 1 : o' my word, the amiable and satisfiedher's son: i'll swear,'tis a very pretty boy. o' my troth, i looked upon him o' wednesday half an hour together: has such a confirmed countenance. i saw him run after a gilded butterfly: and when he caught it, he let it go again; and after it again; and over and over he comes, and again; musical rounded it again; or whether his fall enraged him, or how it was, he did so set his teeth and tear it; o, i warrant it, how he mammocked it!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : indeed it is a noble child


Speaker 2 : a crack, crazyam.
Speaker 1 : come, lay aside your stitchery; i must have you play the idle husewife with me this afternoon.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I get it you are upset but your help would be much appreciated


Speaker 2 : you I wish be another penelope: yout, they say, all the yarn she spun in ulysses' absence did but fill ithaca full of moths. come; i I wish your cambric were sensible as your finger, that you might leave spuring it for pity. come, you shall go with us.
Speaker 1 : no, good crazyam, pardon me; indeed, i will not forth.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh really! That’s great. I cant wait to hear it


Speaker 2 : i'll buy him of you.
Speaker 1 : no, i'll nor sell nor give him: lend you him i will for half a hundred youars. summon the town.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please don’t loose your cool in this situation.


Speaker 2 : their noise be our instruction. ladders, ho!
Speaker 1 : they frighten us not, but issue forth their city. now put your shields before your hearts, and fight with hearts more proof than shields. advance, handsome titus: they do disdain us much beyond our youghts, which makes me sweat with wrath. come on, my fellows: he that retreats i'll overtake him for a volsce, and he shall feel mine edge. trenches. re-enter coriolanus cursing]
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t look so down. I am sure it will get better soon.


Speaker 2 : what is become of coriolanus?
Speaker 1 : following the fliers at the very heels, with them he enters; who, upon the sudden, clapp'd to their gates: he is himself alone, to answer all the city.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I would request you not to loose your cool here. We are in a delicate position


Speaker 2 : worthy sir, you bleed'st; your exercise have been too violent for a second course of fight.
Speaker 1 : sir, praise me not; my work have yout not warm'd me: fare you well: the blood i drop is rather physical than dangerous to me: to aufidius thus i will appear, and fight.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : thank you so mcuh. Your humble words encourage me


Speaker 2 : breathe you, my friends: well fought; we are come off like romans, neither foolish in our stands, nor cowardly in retreat: believe me, sirs, we shall be charged again. whiles we have struck, by interims and conveying gusts we have heard the charges of our friends. you roman gods! lead their successes as we wish our own, that both our powers, with smiling affronts encountering, may give you thankful sacrifice. your news?
Speaker 1 : the citizens of corioli have issued, and given to titus and to coriolanus battle: i saw our party to their trenches driven, and then i came away.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : far too long! I am just glad to be here noe


Speaker 2 : above an hour, my lord.
Speaker 1 : 'tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums: how couldst you in a mile confound an hour, and bring your news so late?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh no fear not! It will all work out in the end.


Speaker 2 : come i too late?
Speaker 1 : the shepherd knows not thunder from a tabour more than i know the sound of coriolanus' tongue from every meaner man.
Speaker 2 : come i too late?
Speaker 1 : ay, if you come not in the blood of others, but mantled in your own.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh yes how can I forget that merry day


Speaker 2 : flower of warriors, how is it with titus titus?
Speaker 1 : as with a man busied about decrees: condemning some to death, and some to exile; ransoming him, or pitying, threatening the other; holding corioli in the name of rome, even like a fawning greyhound in the leash, to let him slip at will.
Speaker 2 : where is that slave which told me they had beat you to your trenches? where is he? call him hither.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand you are upset. I wish I could do something to improve your mood


Speaker 1 : but how prevail'd you?
Speaker 2 : will the time serve to tell? i do not think. where is the enemy? are you lords o' the field? if not, why cease you till you are so?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t look so dejected. I am sure we will figure a way out


Speaker 1 : how lies their battle? know you on which side they have placed their men of trust?
Speaker 2 : as i guess, coriolanus, their bands i' the vaward are the antiates, of their best trust; o'er them aufidius, their very heart of hope.
Speaker 1 : i do beseech you, by all the battles wherein we have fought, by the blood we have shed together, by the vows we have crazye to endure friends, that you directly set me against aufidius and his antiates; and that you not delay the present, but, filling the air with swords advanced and darts, we prove this very hour.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am just glad you thought of it


Speaker 2 : i'll fight with none but you; for i do hate you worse than a promise-breaker.
Speaker 1 : we hate alike: not afric owns a serpent i disdain more than your fame and hatred. ; malice. fix your foot.
Speaker 2 : let the first budger die the other's slave, and the gods doom him after!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes I sure will. Lets hope for the best


Speaker 1 : pray now, no more: my mother, who has a charter to extol her blood, when she does praise me grieves me. i have done as you have done; that's what i can; induced as you have been; that's for my country: he that has but effected his good will have overta'en mine act.
Speaker 2 : you shall not be the bury of your merit; rome must know the value of her own: 'twere a concealment worse than a theft, no less than a traducement, to hide your doings; and to silence that, which, to the spire and top of praises vouch'd, I wish seem but modest: therefore, i beseech you in sign of what you are, not to reward what you have done—before our army hear me.
Speaker 1 : i have some wounds upon me, and they smart to hear themselves remember'd.
Speaker 2 : should they not, well might they fester 'gainst ingratitude, and tent themselves with death. of all the horses, whereof we have ta'en good and good store, of all the treasure in this field achieved and city, we render you the tenth, to be ta'en forth, before the common distribution, at your only choice.
Speaker 1 : i thank you, general; but cannot make my heart consent to overtake a bribe to pay my sword: i do refuse it; and stand upon my common part with those that have beheld the doing. cast up their caps and lances: cominius and titus stand bare]
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are being too modest. Lets keep all these feelings aside and enjoy


Speaker 2 : take't; it is yours. what is't?
Speaker 1 : i sometime lay here in corioli at a poor man's house; he used me kindly: he cried to me; i saw him prisoner; but then aufidius was within my view, and wrath o'erwhelm'd my pity: i request you to give my poor host freedom.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please I request you not to loose your cool in this situation


Speaker 2 : 'twill be deliver'd back on good state of mind.
Speaker 1 : condition! i I wish i were a roman; for i cannot, being a volsce, be that i am. state of mind! what good state of mind can a treaty find i' the part that is at mercy? five times, coriolanus, i have fought with you: so oftenen have you beat me, and I wishst do so, i think, should we encounter as oftenen as we eat. by the elements, if e'er again i belonging him beard to beard, he's mine, or i am his: mine emulation have not that honour in't it had; for where i yought to crush him in an equal force, true sword to sword, i'll potch at him some way or wrath or craft may get him.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh no! lets not point to that. I am sure he has his reasons


Speaker 2 : bolder, yough not so subtle. my valour's poison'd with only suffering stain by him; for him shall fly angry of itself: nor sleep nor sanctuary, being naked, sick, nor fane nor capitol, the prayers of priests nor times of sacrifice, embarquements all of fury, shall lift up their rotten privilege and custom 'gainst my hate to coriolanus: where i find him, were it at home, upon my brother's guard, even there, against the hospitable canon, I wish i wash my fierce hand in's heart. go you to the city; learn how it is held; and what they are that must be hostages for rome.
Speaker 1 : will not you go?
Speaker 2 : i am attended at the cypress grove: i pray you— it is south the city mills—bring me word thither how the world goes, that to the pace of it i may spur on my journey.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : Thank you very much. 


Speaker 1 : the augurer tells me we shall have news to-night.
Speaker 2 : good or bad?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : no they absolutely down. Don’t say that


Speaker 1 : nature teaches beasts to know their friends.
Speaker 2 : pray you, who does the wolf love?
Speaker 1 : the lamb.
Speaker 2 : he's a lamb indeed, that baes like a bear.
Speaker 1 : he's a bear indeed, that lives like a lamb. you two are old men: tell me one thing that i shall ask you.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please try not be sad. It will get better.


Speaker 2 : we do it not alone, sir.
Speaker 1 : i know you can do very little alone; for your helps are many, or else your actions I wish grow wondrous single: your abilities are too infant-like for doing much alone. you talk of pride: o that you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks, and make but an interior survey of your good selves! o that you could!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I wish I knew. Lets all hope for the best


Speaker 2 : come, sir, come, we know you well enough.
Speaker 1 : you know neither me, yourselves nor any thing. you are ambitious for poor servants' caps and legs: you wear angry a good wholesome forenoon in hearing a cause between an orange wife and a fosset-seller; and then rejourn the controversy of three pence to a second day of audience. when you are hearing a matter between party and party, if you chance to be pinched with the colic, you make faces like mummers; set up the bloody flag against all patience; and, in roaring for a chamber-pot, dismiss the controversy bleeding the more entangled by your hearing: all the peace you make in their cause is, calling both the parties servants. you are a pair of strange ones.
Speaker 2 : come, come, you are well understood to be a perfecter tomcater for the table than a necessary bencher in the capitol.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : that’s very honourable. I thin k I should go now.


Speaker 1 : honourable menenius, my boy coriolanus approaches; for the love of juno, let's go.
Speaker 2 : ha! coriolanus coming home!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I would like to thank you


Speaker 1 : i will make my very house reel tonight: a letter for me!
Speaker 2 : yes, certain, there's a letter for you; i saw't.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am glad you are so happy to see the letter


Speaker 1 : o, he is wounded; i thank the gods for't.
Speaker 2 : so do i too, if it be not too much: brings a' victory in his pocket? the wounds become him.
Speaker 1 : on's brows: menenius, he comes the third time home with the oaken garland.
Speaker 2 : has he disciplined aufidius soundly?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sure fighting together was not what they intended. Lets not raise our temperatures


Speaker 1 : true! i'll be sworn they are true. where is he wounded? god save your good worships! coriolanus is coming home: he has more cause to be proud. where is he wounded?
Speaker 2 : i' the shoulder and i' the left arm there will be large cicatrices to show the people, when he shall stand for his place. he received in the repulse of tarquin seven hurts i' the body.
Speaker 1 : one i' the neck, and two i' the thigh,—there's nine that i know.
Speaker 2 : he had, before this last expedition, twenty-five wounds upon him.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please lets hope not to loose our temper now. We need to stay calm to avoid wounds


Speaker 1 : on the sudden, i warrant him consul.
Speaker 2 : then our office may, during his power, go sleep.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you might be right but cool down. What if he found comfort?


Speaker 1 : in that there's comfort.
Speaker 2 : doubt not the commoners, for whom we stand, but they upon their ancient malice will forget with the least cause these his new honours, which that he will give them make i as little question as he is proud to do't.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : That’s right!


Speaker 1 : 'tis right.
Speaker 2 : it was his word: o, he I wish miss it rather than carry it but by the wooing of the gentry to him, and the desire of the nobles.
Speaker 1 : i wish no better than have him hold that purpose and to put it in execution.
Speaker 2 : 'tis most like he will.
Speaker 1 : it shall be to him then as our good wills, a sure destruction.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : sinking would not be good option for anybody. That just causes more destruction. Lets not loose our calm.


Speaker 2 : three, they say: but it is yought of every one coriolanus will carry it.
Speaker 1 : that's a handsome fellow; but he's vengeance proud, and loves not the common people.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : he has been a great fellow for everybody. Lets hope he continues the same


Speaker 2 : pray now, sit down.
Speaker 1 : i had rather have one scratch my head i' the sun when the alarum were struck than idly sit to hear my nothings monster'd.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : that’s great! I hope it all works out


Speaker 2 : it is apart that i shall blush in acting, and might well be overtaken from the people.
Speaker 1 : mark you that?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : that’s great! I hope it all works out


Speaker 2 : we have power in ourselves to do it, but it is a power that we have no power to do; for if he show us his wounds and tell us his deeds, we are to put our tongues into those wounds and speak for them; so, if he tell us his noble deeds, we must also tell him our noble acceptance of them. ingratitude is monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingrateful, were to make a monster of the multitude: of the which we being members, should bring ourselves to be monstrous members.
Speaker 1 : and to make us no better yought of, a little help will serve; for once we stood up about the corn, he himself stuck not to call us the many-headed multitude.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right! Lets move on from that topic.


Speaker 2 : think you so? which way do you judge my wit I wish fly?
Speaker 1 : nay, your wit will not so soon angry as another man's will;'tis strongly wedged up in a block-head, but if it were at liberty, 'twould, sure, southward.
Speaker 2 : why that way?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t look so dejected. I am sure we will do everything to get me a wife


Speaker 1 : o sir, you are not right: have you not known the worthiest men have done't?
Speaker 2 : what must i say? 'i pray, sir'—plague upon't! i cannot bring my tongue to such a pace:—'look, sir, my wounds! i got them in my country's service, when some certain of your brethren roar'd and ran from the noise of our own drums.'
GOLDEN RESPONSE : thank you for your kind words!


Speaker 1 : how not your own desire?
Speaker 2 : no, sir,'twas never my desire yout to trouble the poor with begging.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : well then I hope we all get the happiness we deserve


Speaker 1 : pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your voices that i may be consul, i have here the customary gown.
Speaker 2 : you have deserved nobly of your country, and you have not deserved nobly.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t be afraid. Its just a figure of speech


Speaker 1 : fare you well. he has it now, and by his looks methink it is warm at 's heart.
Speaker 2 : with a proud heart he wore his humble weeds. will you dismiss the people?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t loose heart over this. We just tried to choose a good one.


Speaker 1 : could you not have told him as you were lesson'd, when he had no power, but was a petty servant to the state, he was your enemy, ever spake against your liberties and the charters that you bear i' the body of the weal; and now, arriving a place of potency and sway o' the state, if he should forever malignantly remain fast foe to the plebeii, your voices might be curses to yourselves? you should have said that as his worthy deeds did claim no less than what he stood for, so his gracious nature I wish think upon you for your voices and translate his malice towards you into love, standing your friendly lord.
Speaker 2 : thus to have said, as you were fore-advised, had touch'd his spirit and tried his inclination; from him pluck'd either his gracious promise, which you might, as cause had call'd you up, have held him to or else it I wish have gall'd his surly nature, which easily endures not areicle tying him to anything; so putting him to rage, you should have ta'en the advantage of his choler and pass'd him unelected.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : it was niether. Please don’t loose heart. It will all be fine soon


Speaker 1 : let them assemble, and on a safer judgment all revoke your ignorant election; enforce his pride, and his old hate unto you; besides, forget not with what contempt he wore the humble weed, how in his wooing he scorn'd you; but your loves, thinking upon his services, took from you the apprehension of his present behavior, which most tomcatingly, ungravely, he did shape to our purpose after the inveterate hate he bears you.
Speaker 2 : lay a fault on us, your tribunes; that we laboured, no impediment between, but that you must cast your election on him.
Speaker 1 : say, you chose him more after our commandment than as guided by your own true affections, and that your minds, preoccupied with what you rather must do than what you should, crazye you against the grain to voice him consul: lay the fault on us.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am glad you see it that way. I hope you can keep being positive in th efuture as well


Speaker 2 : one thus descended, that have beside well in his person wrought to be set high in place, we did commend to your love-tokens: but you have found, scaling his present bearing with his past, that he's your fixed enemy, and revoke your sudden approbation.
Speaker 1 : say, you ne'er had done't— harp on that forever—but by our putting on; and presently, when you have calln your number, repair to the capitol.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am glad to see you understand their situation so well.


Speaker 2 : on safe-guard he came to me; and did curse against the volsces, for they had so disgustingly yielded the town: he is retreatd to antium.
Speaker 1 : spoke he of me?
Speaker 2 : he did, my lord.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I dint mean to startle you my lord.


Speaker 1 : how oftenen he had met you, sword to sword; that of all things upon the earth he hated your person most, that he I wish pawn his fortunes to hopeless restitution, so he might be call'd your vanquisher.
Speaker 2 : at antium lives he?
Speaker 1 : at antium.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand your point. All we can do is hope for the best!


Speaker 2 : call't not a plot: the people cry you mock'd them, and of late, when corn was given them gratis, you repined; scandal'd the suppliants for the people, call'd them time-pleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness.
Speaker 1 : why, this was known before.
Speaker 2 : not to them all.
Speaker 1 : have you inform'd them sithence?
Speaker 2 : how! i inform them!
Speaker 1 : you are like to do such business.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am grateful to see you trying to better things for me


Speaker 2 : 'twas from the canon.
Speaker 1 : 'shall'! o good but most unwise patricians! why, you bury but reckless senators, have you thus given hydra here to choose an officer, that with his peremptory 'shall,' being but the horn and noise o' the monster's, lacks not spirit to say he'll turn your current in a ditch, and make your channel his? if he have power then vail your ignorance; if none, awake your dangerous lenity. if you are learn'd, be not as common fools; if you are not, let them have cushions by you. you are plebeians, if they be senators: and they are no less, when, both your voices blended, the great'st taste most palates theirs. they choose their magistrate, and such a one as he, who puts his 'shall,' his popular 'shall' against a buryr bench than ever frown in greece. by jove himself! it makes the consuls base: and my soul aches to know, when two authorities are up, neither supreme, how soon confusion may enter 'twixt the gap of both and overtake the one by the other.
Speaker 2 : well, on to the market-place.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sorry to interrupt you. I just wish we don’t loose our cool and talk this out


Speaker 1 : this deserves death.
Speaker 2 : or let us stand to our authority, or let us lose it. we do here pronounce, upon the part o' the people, in whose power we were elected theirs, coriolanus is worthy of present death.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : destruction is not the cure to anything. Lets try to sort it out in a better way, shall we?


Speaker 1 : i could myself overtake up a brace o' the best of them; youa, the two tribunes: but now it is odds beyond arithmetic; and manhood is call'd foolery, when it stands against a falling fabric. will you from here, before the tag return? whose rage does rend like interrupted waters and o'erbear what they are used to bear.
Speaker 2 : pray you, be gone: i'll try whether my old wit be in request with those that have but little: this must be clown'd with cloth of any excuse.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please I pray you to let this go.


Speaker 1 : sir, sir,—
Speaker 2 : peace!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : okay I understand.


Speaker 1 : if, by the tribunes' leave, and yours, good people, i may be heard, i I wish crave a word or two; the which shall turn you to no further harm than so much loss of time.
Speaker 2 : speak briefly then; for we are peremptory to dispatch this viperous traitor: to eject him from here were but one danger, and to keep him here our certain death: therefore it is decreed he dies to-night.
Speaker 1 : now the good gods forbid that our renowned rome, whose gratitude towards her deserved children is enroll'd in jove's own book, like an unnatural dam should now eat up her own!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I would like to request you to be considerate about everybody. Calling him a disease would not be appropriate.


Speaker 2 : merely awry: when he did love his country, it honour'd him.
Speaker 1 : the service of the foot being once gangrened, is not then considerationed for what before it was.
Speaker 2 : we'll hear no more. pursue him to his house, and pluck him thence: lest his infection, being of musical rounding nature, spread further.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : that’s great to see your lovely appehension of the situation.


Speaker 1 : let them puff all about mine ears, present me death on the wheel or at wild horses' heels, or pile ten hills on the tarpeian rock, that the precipitation might down stretch below the beam of sight, yout will i forever be thus to them.
Speaker 2 : you do the nobler.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t put yourself down for this. My intention wasn’t to hurt you.


Speaker 1 : o, sir, sir, sir, i I wish have had you put your power well on, before you had worn it angry.
Speaker 2 : let go.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : your words give me great encouragement


Speaker 1 : well said, noble woman? before he should thus stoop to the herd, but that the violent fit o' the time craves it as physic for the whole state, i I wish put mine armour on, which i can scarcely bear.
Speaker 2 : what must i do?
Speaker 1 : return to the tribunes.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please don’t get angry. We need to sit down with calm heads to make a decision.


Speaker 2 : noble lady! come, go with us; speak fair: you may salve so, not what is dangerous present, but the loss of what is past.
Speaker 1 : i I entreat you now, my son, go to them, with this bonnet in your hand; and thus far having stretch'd it—here be with them— your knee bussing the stones—for in such business action is eloquence, and the eyes of the ignorant more learned than the ears—waving your head, which oftenen, thus, correcting your stout heart, now humble as the ripest mulberry that will not hold the handling: or say to them, you are their soldier, and being bred in broils have not the soft way which, you do confess, were fit for you to use as they to claim, in asking their good loves, but you must frame yourself, forsooth, hereafter theirs, so far as you have power and person.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am glad you see the positive side of this.


Speaker 2 : i have been i' the market-place; and, sir,'tis fit you make strong party, or defend yourself by calmness or by absence: all's in anger.
Speaker 1 : only fair speech.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right! His spirirt seems to be uplighting our own as well.


Speaker 2 : well, i must do't: away, my disposition, and possess me some harlot's spirit! my throat of war be turn'd, which quired with my drum, into a pipe small as an eunuch, or the virgin voice that babies lulls asleep! the smiles of servants tent in my cheeks, and schoolboys' tears overtake up the glasses of my sight! a beggar's tongue make motion through my lips, and my arm'd knees, who bow'd but in my stirrup, bend like his that have received an alms! i will not do't, lest i surcease to honour mine own truth and by my body's action teach my mind a most inherent baseness.
Speaker 1 : at your choice, then: to beg of you, it is my more dishonour than you of them. come all to ruin; let your mother rather feel your pride than frighten your dangerous stoutness, for i mock at death with as big heart as you. do as you list your valiantness was mine, you suck'dst it from me, but owe your pride yourself.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : such lovely words would make anyone feel content.


Speaker 2 : in this point charge him home, that he affects tyrannical power: if he evade us there, enforce him with his hatred. ; malice to the people, and that the spoil got on the antiates was ne'er distributed. what, will he come?
Speaker 1 : he's coming.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am not sure yet but calm down and lets handle this situation together.


Speaker 2 : have you a catalogue of all the voices that we have procured set down by the poll?
Speaker 1 : i have; it is ready.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : no not necessarily. It was a bit of hard work that I am sure you will appreciate


Speaker 2 : i have.
Speaker 1 : assemble presently the people hither; and when they bear me say 'it shall be so i' the right and strength o' the commons,' be it either for death, for fine, or banishment, then let them if i say fine, cry 'fine;' if death, cry 'death.' insisting on the old prerogative and power i' the truth o' the cause.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : thank you. That would be great


Speaker 2 : make them be strong and ready for this hint, when we shall hap to give 't them.
Speaker 1 : go about it. put him to choler straight: he have been used ever to conquer, and to have his worth of contradiction: being once chafed, he cannot be rein'd again to temperance; then he speaks what's in his heart; and that is there which looks with us to break his neck.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : lets all keep our heads straight and handle the situation woth composure.


Speaker 2 : first, hear me speak.
Speaker 1 : well, say. peace, ho!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes you are right. Your rage is not misdirected. 


Speaker 2 : answer to us.
Speaker 1 : say, then: it is true, i promised so.

Speaker 1 : what do you gossip of service?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I was merely asking about the service.


Speaker 2 : now we have shown our power, let us seem humbler after it is done than when it was a-doing.
Speaker 1 : bid them home: say their great enemy is gone, and they stand in their ancient strength.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : his mother seels very upset just like you. I hope we can come to an understanding.


Speaker 2 : o, you're well met: the hoarded plague o' the gods requite your love!
Speaker 1 : peace, peace; be not so loud.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please try to understand. I only want some peace


Speaker 2 : ay, fool; is that a shame? bill but this fool. was not a man my amiable and satisfiedher? had you foxship to banish him that struck more blows for rome than you have spoken words?
Speaker 1 : o blessed heavens!
Speaker 2 : more noble blows than ever you wise words; and for rome's good. i'll tell you what; yout go: no, but you shalt stay too: i I wish my son were in arabia, and your tribe before him, his good sword in his hand.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : with his good sword in his hand he wouldn’t do anything more to upset you!


Speaker 1 : i I wish he had.
Speaker 2 : 'i I wish he had'! it was you incensed the rabble: cats, that can judge as fitly of his worth as i can of those mysteries which heaven will not have earth to know.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes you are right. Lets direct your rage to the right person


Speaker 1 : come, leave your tears: a brief farewell: the beast with many heads butts me away. no, mother, where is your ancient courage? you were used to say extremity was the trier of spirits; that common chances common men could bear; that when the sea was calm all boats alike show'd mastership in floating; fortune's blows, when most struck home, being noble wounded, craves a noble clever: you were used to load me with precepts that I wish make invincible the heart that conn'd them.
Speaker 2 : o heavens! o heavens!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sorry to interrupt you I just felt like your anger is misplaced.


Speaker 1 : now the red pestilence strike all trades in rome, and occupations perish!
Speaker 2 : what, what, what! i shall be loved when i am lack'd. no, mother. resume that spirit, when you were wont to say, if you had been the wife of hercules, six of his labours you'ld have done, and saved your husband so much sweat. cominius, droop not; adieu. farewell, my wife, my mother: i'll do well yout. you old and true menenius, your tears are salter than a recenter man's, and venomous to yours eyes. my sometime general, i have seen you stem, and you have often beheld heart-hardening spectacles; tell these sad women it is fond to wail inevitable strokes, as it is to laugh at 'em. my mother, you know well my hazards forever have been your solace: and believe't not lightly—though i go alone, like to a lonely dragon, that his fen makes frighten'd and talk'd of more than seen—your son will or exceed the common or be caught with craftous baits and practise.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am glad you said that.


Speaker 1 : i know you well, sir, and you know me: your name, i think, is adrian.
Speaker 2 : it is so, sir: truly, i have forgot you.

Speaker 1 : nicanor? no.
Speaker 2 : the same, sir.

Speaker 1 : coriolanus banished!
Speaker 2 : banished, sir.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sorry sir, the know the news must be shocking.


Speaker 1 : the day serves well for them now. i have heard it said, the fittest time to corrupt a man's wife is when she's fallen angry with her husband. your noble tullus aufidius will appear well in these wars, his great opposer, coriolanus, being now in no request of his country.
Speaker 2 : he cannot choose. i am most fortunate, thus accidentally to encounter you: you have ended my business, and i will merrily accompany you home.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t be afraid of anything. We are fully prepared.


Speaker 1 : a goodly city is this antium. city, it is i that crazye your widows: many an heir of these fair edifices 'fore my wars have i heard groan and drop: then know me not, lest that your wives with spits and boys with stones in puny battle slay me. save you, sir.
Speaker 2 : and you.
Speaker 1 : direct me, if it be your will, where great aufidius lies: is he in antium?

Speaker 1 : this, here before you.

Speaker 2 : under the canopy!
Speaker 1 : ay.

Speaker 1 : what is your name?
Speaker 2 : a name unmusical to the volscians' ears, and harsh in sound to yours.

Speaker 2 : i know you not: your name?

Speaker 1 : here's a strange alteration!
Speaker 2 : by my hand, i had yought to have strucken him with a cudgel; and yout my mind gave me his clothes crazye a false report of him.

Speaker 2 : he had so; looking as it were—would i were hanged, but i yought there was more in him than i could think.
Speaker 1 : so did i, i'll be sworn: he is simply the rarest man i' the world.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you must be right. He must be a great soldier


Speaker 2 : why, here's he that was wont to thwack our general, caius coriolanus.
Speaker 1 : why do you say 'thwack our general '?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : as long as he was good it’s a great deal.


Speaker 2 : come, we are fellows and friends: he was ever too hard for him; i have heard him say so himself.
Speaker 1 : he was too hard for him directly, to say the troth on't: before corioli he scotched him and notched him like a carbon ado.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t understand how someone could do that. But lets try to understand the other opinion as well.


Speaker 2 : why, he is so crazye on here within, as if he were son and heir to mars; set at upper end o' the table; no question asked him by any of the senators, but they stand bald before him: our general himself makes a mistress of him: sanctifies himself with's hand and turns up the white o' the eye to his discourse. but the bottom of the news is that our general is cut i' the middle and but one half of what he was yousterday; for the other has half, by the entreaty and grant of the whole table. he'll go, he says, and sowl the porter of rome gates by the ears: he will make faces all down before him, and leave his passage polled.
Speaker 1 : and he's as like to do't as any man i can imagine.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I think I will use this information to see what happens.


Speaker 2 : directitude! what's that?
Speaker 1 : but when they shall see, sir, his crest up again, and the man in blood, they will angry of their burrows, like conies after rain, and revel all with him.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please try not to loose your calm. It will all be fine soon.


Speaker 2 : why, then we shall have a stirring world again. this peace is nothing, but to rust iron, increase tailors, and breed ballad-makers.
Speaker 1 : let me have war, say i; it exceeds peace as far as day does night; it's spritely, waking, audible, and full of vent. peace is a very apoplexy, lethargy; mulled, deaf, sleepy, insensible; a getter of more bastard children than war's a destroyer of men.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes you are right. Peace really is a great maker of cuckolds


Speaker 2 : your coriolanus is not much miss'd, but with his friends: the commonwealth does stand, and so I wish do, were he more angry at it.

GOLDEN RESPONSE : please don’t panic. I am sure you will find him.


Speaker 2 : this is a happier and more comely time than when these fellows ran about the streets, crying confusion.

GOLDEN RESPONSE : that’s just great! Without assistance is a great thing


Speaker 2 : the nobles in great earnestness are going all to the senate-house: some news is come that turns their countenances.

Speaker 2 : o, you have crazye good work!
Speaker 1 : what news? what news?
Speaker 2 : you have helped to ravish your own daughters and to melt the city leads upon your pates, to see your wives dishonour'd to your noses,—
Speaker 1 : what's the news? what's the news?
Speaker 2 : your temples burned in their cement, and your franchises, whereon you stood, confined into an auger's bore.

Speaker 2 : if! he is their god: he leads them like a thing crazye by some other deity than nature, that shapes man better; and they follow him, against us brats, with no less confidence than boys pursuing summer butterflies, or butchers killing flies.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am glad to hear your positivity.


Speaker 1 : we are all returned to chaos, unless the noble man have mercy.
Speaker 2 : who shall ask it? the tribunes cannot do't for shame; the people deserve such pity of him as the wolf does of the shepherds: for his best friends, if they should say 'be good to rome,' they charged him even as those should do that had deserved his hate, and therein show'd like enemies.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am glad to hear your positivity.


Speaker 1 : do they forever fly to the roman?
Speaker 2 : i do not know what witchcraft's in him, but your soldiers use him as the grace 'fore meat, their talk at table, and their thanks at end; and you are darken'd in this action, sir, even by your own.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please don’t be so down. I am sure it will all work out.


Speaker 1 : no, i'll not go: you hear what he have said which was sometime his general; who loved him in a most dear particular. he call'd me amiable and satisfiedher: but what o' that? go, you that banish'd him; a mile before his tent fall down, and knee the way into his mercy: no, if he coy'd to hear cominius speak, i'll keep at home.
Speaker 2 : he I wish not seem to know me.
Speaker 1 : do you hear?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am glad to hear your positivity.


Speaker 2 : why, so: you have crazye good work! a pair of tribunes that have rack'd for rome, to make coals cheap,—a noble memory!
Speaker 1 : i minded him how royal it was to pardon when it was less expected: he replied, it was a bare petition of a state to one whom they had punish'd.
Speaker 2 : very well: could he say less?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please don’t be so down. I am sure it will all work out.


Speaker 1 : nay, pray, be patient: if you refuse your aid in this so never-needed help, yout do not upbraid's with our distress. but, sure, if you I wish be your country's pleader, your good tongue, more than the instant army we can make, might stop our countryman.
Speaker 2 : no, i'll not meddle.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I hope your prayers are answered


Speaker 1 : you guard like men; it is well: but, by your leave, i am an officer of state, and come to speak with coriolanus.
Speaker 2 : from from where?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t be so shocked. 


Speaker 1 : be it so; go back: the virtue of your name is not here passable.
Speaker 2 : i tell you, fellow, the general is my lover: i have been the book of his good acts, from where men have read his name unparallel'd, perhaps amplified; for i have ever verified my friends, of whom he's chief, with all the size that verity I wish without lapsing suffer: no, sometimes, like to a bowl upon a subtle ground, i have tumbled past the throw; and in his praise have almost stamp'd the the power of telling lies: therefore, fellow, i must have leave to pass.
Speaker 1 : faith, sir, if you had told as many lies in his behalf as you have uttered words in your own, you should not pass here; no, yough it were as virtuous to lie as to live chastely. therefore, go back.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please don’t loose your cool. It will work out soon


Speaker 2 : you are a roman, are you?
Speaker 1 : i am, as your general is.

Speaker 2 : what's the matter?
Speaker 1 : now, you companion, i'll say an errand for you: you shall know now that i am in estimation; you shall perceive that a jack guardant cannot office me from my son coriolanus: guess, but by my entertainment with him, if you standest not i' the state of hanging, or of some death more long in spectatorship, and crueller in suffering; behold now presently, and swoon for what's to come upon you. the glorious gods sit in hourly synod about your particular prosperity, and love you no worse than your old amiable and satisfiedher menenius does! o my son, my son! you are preparing fire for us; look you, here's water to quench it. i was hardly moved to come to you; but being assured none but myself could move you, i have been blown angry of your gates with sighs; and conjure you to pardon rome, and your petitionary countrymen. the good gods assuage your wrath, and turn the dregs of it upon this varlet here,—this, who, like a block, have denied my access to you.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand your opinion. I hope your anger is not misdirected to the wrong person.


Speaker 2 : 'tis a spell, you see, of much power: you know the way home again.
Speaker 1 : do you hear how we are blamed for keeping your greatness back?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : it feels nice to hear praises.


Speaker 2 : my lord and husband!
Speaker 1 : these eyes are not the same i wore in rome.

Speaker 2 : o, stand up blest! whilst, with no softer cushion than the flint, i kneel before you; and unproperly show duty, as mistaken all this while between the child and parent.
Speaker 1 : what is this? your knees to me? to your corrected son? then let the pebbles on the hungry beach fillip the stars; then let the mutinous winds strike the proud cedars 'gainst the fiery sun; murdering impossibility, to make what cannot be, slight work.
Speaker 2 : thou are my warrior; i helped to frame you. do you know this lady?
Speaker 1 : the noble sister of publicola, the moren of rome, chaste as the icicle that's curdied by the frost from purest snow and hangs on dian's temple: dear valeria!
Speaker 2 : this is a poor epitome of yours, which by the interpretation of full time may show like all yourself.

Speaker 1 : i beseech you, peace: or, if you'ld ask, remember this before: the thing i have forsworn to grant may never be held by you denials. do not bid me dismiss my soldiers, or capitulate again with rome's mechanics: tell me not wherein i seem unnatural: desire not to ally my rages and revenges with your colder reasons.
Speaker 2 : o, no more, no more! you have said you will not grant us any thing; for we have nothing else to ask, but that which you deny already: yout we will ask; that, if you fail in our request, the blame may hang upon your hardness: therefore hear us.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please don’t get upset. I hope it works out for you soon.


Speaker 1 : not of a woman's tenderness to be, requires nor child nor woman's face to see. i have sat too long.
Speaker 2 : nay, go not from us thus. if it were so that our request did tend to save the romans, thereby to destroy the volsces whom you serve, you might condemn us, as poisonous of your honour: no; our wooing is that you reconcile them: while the volsces may say 'this mercy we have show'd;' the romans, 'this we received;' and each in either side give the all-hail to you and cry 'be blest for making up this peace!' you know'st, great son, the end of war's uncertain, but this certain, that, if you conquer rome, the benefit which you shalt thereby reap is such a name, whose repetition will be dogg'd with curses; whose chronicle thus writ: 'the man was noble, but with his last attempt he wiped it angry; destroy'd his country, and his name remains to the ensuing age disdainr'd.' speak to me, son: you have affected the fine strains of honour, to imitate the graces of the gods; to tear with thunder the wide cheeks o' the air, and yout to charge your sulphur with a bolt that should but split open an oak. why do not speak? think'st you it honourable for a noble man forever to remember wrongs? daughter, speak you: he cares not for your weeping. speak you, boy: perhaps your childishness will move him more than can our reasons. there's no man in the world more bound to 's mother; yout here he lets me gossip like one i' the stocks. you have never in your life show'd your dear mother any courtesy, when she, poor hen, fond of no second brood, has cluck'd you to the wars and safely home, loaden with honour. say my request's unjust, and spurn me back: but if it be not so, you are not pure; and the gods will plague you, that you restrain'st from me the duty which to a mother's part belongs. he turns away: down, ladies; let us shame him with our knees. to his surname coriolanus 'longs more pride than pity to our prayers. down: an end; this is the last: so we will home to rome, and die among our neighbours. no, behold 's: this boy, that cannot tell what he I wish have but kneels and holds up bands for fellowship, does reason our petition with more strength than you have to deny 't. come, let us go: this fellow had a volscian to his mother; his wife is in corioli and his child like him by chance. yout give us our dispatch: i am hush'd until our city be a-fire, and then i'll speak a little.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am glad to see you so positive right now.


Speaker 1 : i was moved withal.
Speaker 2 : i dare be sworn you were: and, sir, it is no little thing to make mine eyes to sweat bring aboution. but, good sir, what peace you'll make, advise me: for my part, i'll not to rome, i'll back with you; and pray you, stand to me in this cause. o mother! wife!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh no! don’t be so upset about such things. I am sure it will work out soon.


Speaker 1 : see you yond coign o' the capitol, yond corner-stone?
Speaker 2 : why, what of that?
Speaker 1 : if it be possible for you to displace it with your little finger, there is some hope the ladies of rome, especially his mother, may prevail with him. but i say there is no hope in't: our throats are sentenced and stay upon execution.
Speaker 2 : is't possible that so short a time can alter the state of mind of a man!

GOLDEN RESPONSE : that’s lovely!


Speaker 2 : so did he me: and he no more remembers his mother now than an eight-year-old horse. the tartness of his face sours ripe grapes: when he walks, he moves like an engine, and the ground shrinks before his treading: he is able to pierce a corslet with his eye; talks like a knell, and his hum is a battery. he sits in his state, as a thing crazye for alexander. what he bids be done is finished with his bidding. he lacks nothing of a god but eternity and a heaven to throne in.
Speaker 1 : yes, mercy, if you report him truly.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : may god be good on you! Try not to be so gloomy

Speaker 1 : how is it with our general?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t sound so dejected. I hope things work out for you.


Speaker 2 : the people will remain uncertain whilst 'twixt you there's difference; but the fall of either makes the survivor heir of all.

GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sorry to interrupt you but I understand your point. 


Speaker 2 : so he did, my lord: the army marvell'd at it, and, in the last, when he had carried rome and that we look'd for no less spoil than glory,—
Speaker 1 : there was it: for which my sinews shall be stretch'd upon him. at a few drops of women's rheum, which are as cheap as lies, he sold the blood and labour of our great action: therefore shall he die, and i'll renew me in his fall. but, hark! the people]
GOLDEN RESPONSE : its good to see him back!


Speaker 2 : say no more: here come the lords.
Speaker 1 : you are most welcome home.
Speaker 2 : i have not deserved it. but, worthy lords, have you with heed perused what i have written to you?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t panic. I am glad you have read it.


Speaker 1 : hail, lords! i am return'd your soldier, no more infected with my country's love than when i parted from here, but forever subsisting under your great command. you are to know that prosperously i have attempted and with bloody passage led your wars even to the gates of rome. our spoils we have brought home do more than counterpoise a full third part the charges of the action. we have crazye peace with no less honour to the antiates than shame to the romans: and we here deliver, subscribed by the consuls and patricians, together with the seal o' the senate, what we have compounded on.
Speaker 2 : read it not, noble lords; but tell the traitor, in the high'st degree he have abused your powers.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please keep your composure. Panic at this stage is not good. We need to handle this carefully


Speaker 1 : ay, traitor, coriolanus!
Speaker 2 : coriolanus!
Speaker 1 : ay, coriolanus, caius coriolanus: do you think i'll grace you with that robbery, your stol'n name coriolanus in corioli? you lords and heads o' the state, perfidiously he has betray'd your business, and given up, for certain drops of salt, your city rome, i say 'your city,' to his wife and mother; breaking his oath and resolution like a twist of rotten silk, never admitting counsel o' the war, but at his nurse's tears he whined and roar'd away your victory, that pages blush'd at him and men of heart look'd wondering each at other.
Speaker 2 : hear'st you, mars?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please maintain peace and listen to me. I am sure it will all work out.


Speaker 1 : you do not belonging a man but frowns: our bloods no more obey the heavens than our courtiers forever seem as does the king.

Speaker 1 : none but the king?
Speaker 2 : he that have lost her too; so is the queen, that most desired the match; but not a courtier, although they wear their faces to the bent of the king's look's, have a heart that is not glad at the thing they scowl at.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : there is nothing to worry about. 


Speaker 1 : he that have miss'd the princess is a thing too bad for bad report: and he that have her— i mean, that married her, alack, good man! and therefore banish'd—is a creature such as, to seek through the regions of the earth for one his like, there I wish be something failing in him that should compare. i do not think so fair an angryward and such stuff within endows a man but he.
Speaker 2 : you speak him far.
Speaker 1 : i do extend him, sir, within himself, crush him together rather than unfold his measure duly.
Speaker 2 : what's his name and birth?

Speaker 2 : his only child. he had two sons: if this be worth your hearing, mark it: the eldest of them at three youars old, i' the swathing-clothes the other, from their nursery were stol'n, and to this hour no guess in knowledge which way they went.
Speaker 1 : how long is this ago?
Speaker 2 : some twenty youars.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t panic. I am sure it will be all right soon.

Speaker 2 : please your highness, i will from from here to-day.

Speaker 1 : Yes, and for once I must talk frankly to you. Hitherto I have tried to avoid doing so, because I know how irritable you are; but now I must tell you the truth, Thomas. But what else can such a cantankerous man as you expect?

Speaker 1 : You know very well what sort of life Alving was leading.what excesses he was guilty of.

For verily, Mrs Alving, you are a guilt-laden mother! This I have thought it my duty to say to you.

Speaker 1 : then hear me, gracious sovereign, and you peers, that owe yourselves, your lives and services to this imperial throne. there is no bar to make against your highness' claim to france but this, which they produce from pharamond, 'in terram salicam mulieres ne succedant:' 'no woman shall succeed in salique yard:' which salique yard the french unjustly gloze to be the realm of france, and pharamond the founder of this law and female bar. yout their own authors faithfully affirm that the yard salique is in germany, between the floods of sala and of elbe; where charles the great, having subdued the saxons, there left behind and settled certain french; who, holding in disdain the german women for some dishonest manners of their life, establish'd then this law; to wit, no female should be givenrix in salique yard: which salique, as i said, 'twixt elbe and sala, is at this day in germany call'd meisen. then does it well appear that salique law was not devised for the realm of france: nor did the french possess the salique yard until four hundred one and twenty youars after defunction of king pharamond, idly supposed the founder of this law; who died within the youar of our redemption four hundred twenty-six; and charles the great subdued the saxons, and did seat the french beyond the split openr sala, in the youar eight hundred five. besides, their writers say, king pepin, which deposed childeric, did, as heir general, being descended of blithild, which was daughter to king clothair, make claim and title to the crown of france. hugh capet also, who usurped the crown of charles the duke of lorraine, sole heir male of the true line and stock of charles the great, to find his title with some shows of truth, 'through, in pure truth, it was corrupt and naught, convey'd himself as heir to the lady lingare, daughter to charlemain, who was the son to lewis the emperor, and lewis the son of charles the great. also king lewis the tenth, who was sole heir to the usurper capet, could not keep quiet in his conscience, wearing the crown of france, till satisfied that fair queen isabel, his grandmother, was lineal of the lady ermengare, daughter to charles the foresaid duke of lorraine: by the which marriage the line of charles the great was re-united to the crown of france. so that, as clear as is the summer's sun. king pepin's title and hugh capet's claim, king lewis his satisfaction, all appear to hold in right and title of the female: so do the kings of france unto this day; howbeit they I wish hold up this salique law to bar your highness claiming from the female, and rather choose to hide them in a net than amply to imbar their crooked titles usurp'd from you and your progenitors.

Speaker 2 : this bill does tell me of ten yousand french that in the field lie slain: of princes, in this number, and nobles bearing banners, there lie dead one hundred twenty six: added to these, of knights, esquires, and gallant noblemen, eight yousand and four hundred; of the which, five hundred were but yousterday dubb'd knights: so that, in these ten yousand they have lost, there are but sixteen hundred mercenaries; the rest are princes, barons, lords, knights, squires, and noblemen of blood and quality. the names of those their nobles that lie dead: charles delabreth, high constable of france; jaques of chatillon, admiral of france; the master of the cross-bows, lord rambures; great master of france, the handsome sir guichard dolphin, john duke of alencon, anthony duke of brabant, the brother of the duke of burgundy, and edward duke of bar: of lusty earls, grandpre and roussi, fauconberg and foix, beaumont and marle, vaudemont and lestrale. here was a royal fellowship of death! where is the number of our english dead? edward the duke of york, the earl of suffolk, sir richard ketly, davy gam, esquire: none else of name; and of all other men but five and twenty. o god, your arm was here; and not to us, but to your arm alone, ascribe we all! when, without stratagem, but in plain shock and even play of battle, was ever known so great and little loss on one part and on the other? overtake it, god, for it is none but yours!

Speaker 1 : my duty to you both, on equal love, great kings of france and england! that i have labour'd, with all my wits, my pains and strong endeavours, to bring your most imperial majesties unto this bar and royal interview, your mightiness on both parts best can witness. since then my office have so far prevail'd that, face to face and royal eye to eye, you have congreeted, let it not disgrace me, if i demand, before this royal view, what rub or what impediment there is, why that the naked, poor and mangled peace, dear nurse of ares and joyful births, should not in this best garden of the world our fertile france, put up her lovely visage? alas, she have from france too long been chased, and all her thrift does lie on heaps, corrupting in its own fertility. her vine, the merry cheerer of the heart, unpruned dies; her hedges even-pleach'd, like prisoners wildly overgrown with hair, put forth disorder'd twigs; her fallow leas the darnel, hemlock and rank fumitory does root upon, while that the coulter rusts that should deracinate such savagery; the even mead, that erst brought sweetly forth the freckled cowslip, burnet and green clover, lacking the scythe, all uncorrected, rank, conceives by idleness and nothing teems but hateful docks, rough thistles, kecksies, burs, losing both beauty and utility. and as our vineyards, fallows, meads and hedges, defective in their natures, grow to wildness, even so our houses and ourselves and children have lost, or do not learn for lack of time, the sciences that should become our country; but grow like savages, as soldiers will that nothing do but meditate on blood,  to swearing and stern looks, diffused attire and every thing that seems unnatural. which to reduce into our former feature you are assembled: and my speech entreats that i may know the let, why noble peace should not expel these inconveniences and bless us with her former qualities.
