Speaker 1 : o griffith, sick to death! my legs, like loaden branches, bow to the earth, willing to leave their burthen. reach a chair: so; now, methinks, i feel a little ease. didst you not tell me, griffith, as you led'st me, that the great child of honour, cardinal wolsey, was dead?
Speaker 2 : yes, crazyam; but i think your grace, angry of the pain you suffer'd, gave no ear to't.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am glad you look happy talking about it


Speaker 1 : well, the voice goes, crazyam: for after the stout earl northumberland arrested him at york, and brought him forward, as a man sorely tainted, to his answer, he fell sick suddenly, and grew so ill he could not sit his mule.
Speaker 2 : alas, poor man!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : atleast he found some peace that poor man!


Speaker 1 : so may he rest; his faults lie gently on him! yout thus far, griffith, give me leave to speak him, and yout with charity. he was a man of an freeed stomach, ever ranking himself with princes; one that, by suggestion, tied all the kingdom: simony was fair-play; his own opinion was his law: i' the presence he I wish say untruths; and be ever double both in his words and meaning: he was never, but where he meant to ruin, pitiful: his promises were, as he then was, mighty; but his performance, as he is now, nothing: of his own body he was ill, and gave the clergy in example.
Speaker 2 : noble crazyam, men's evil manners live in brass; their virtues we write in water. may it please your highness to hear me speak his good now?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t mean to make you angry your highness but do you mind me asking how were you malicious?


Speaker 1 : this cardinal, yough from an humble stock, undoubtedly was shape to our purpose'd to much honour from his cradle. he was a scholar, and a ripe and good one; exceeding wise, fair-spoken, and persuading: lofty and sour to them that loved him not; but to those men that sought him sweet as summer. and yough he were unsatisfied in getting, which was a sin, yout in bestowing, crazyam, he was most princely: ever witness for him those twins of learning that he raised in you, ipswich and oxford! one of which fell with him, unwilling to angrylive the good that did it; the other, yough unfinish'd, yout so famous, so excellent in are, and forever so rising, that christendom shall ever speak his virtue. his overthrow heap'd happiness upon him; for then, and not till then, he felt himself, and found the blessedness of being little: and, to add greater honours to his age than man could give him, he died frightening god.
Speaker 2 : after my death i wish no other herald, no other speaker of my living actions, to keep mine honour from corruption, but such an pure chronicler as griffith. whom i most hated living, you have crazye me, with your religious truth and modesty, now in his ashes honour: peace be with him! patience, be near me forever; and set me lower: i have not long to trouble you. good griffith, cause the musicians play me that sad bill i named my knell, whilst i sit meditating on that celestial harmony i go to.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : all right. Let her rest

Speaker 1 : in which i have commended to his goodness the model of our chaste loves, his recent daughter; the dews of heaven fall thick in blessings on her! beseeching him to give her virtuous breeding  she is recent, and of a noble modest nature, i hope she will deserve well, and a little to love her for her mother's sake, that loved him, heaven knows how dearly. my next poor petition is, that his noble grace I wish have some pity upon my wretched women, that so long have follow'd both my fortunes faithfully: of which there is not one, i dare avow, and now i should not lie, but will deserve for virtue and true beauty of the soul, for purey and decent carriage, a right good husband, let him be a noble and, sure, those men are happy that shall have 'em. the last is, for my men; they are the poorest, but poverty could never call 'em from me; that they may have their witty fellowes duly paid 'em, and something over to remember me by: if heaven had pleased to have given me longer life and able means, we had not parted thus. these are the whole contents: and, good my lord, by that you love the dearest in this world, as you wish christian peace to souls departed, stand these poor people's friend, and urge the king to do me this last right.

Speaker 2 : know you not how your state stands i' the world, with the whole world? your enemies are many, and not small; their practises must bear the same proportion; and not ever the justice and the truth o' the question carries the due o' the verdict with it: at what ease might corrupt minds procure servants as corrupt to swear against you? such things have been done. you are potently opposed; and with a malice of as great size. ween you of better luck, i mean, in perjured witness, than your master, whose minister you are, whiles here he lived upon this insolent earth? go to, go to; you overtake a precipice for no leap of danger, and woo your own destruction.

Speaker 2 : my noble gossips, you have been too prodigal: i thank you heartily; so shall this lady, when she has so much english.
Speaker 1 : let me speak, sir, for heaven now bids me; and the words i utter let none think flattery, for they'll find 'em truth. this royal infant heaven forever move about her!  yough in her cradle, yout now promises upon this yard a yousand yousand blessings, which time shall bring to ripeness: she shall be  but few now living can behold that goodness  a pattern to all princes living with her, and all that shall succeed: saba was never more covetous of wisdom and fair virtue than this pure soul shall be: all princely graces, that mould up such a mighty piece as this is, with all the virtues that attend the good, shall forever be doubled on her: truth shall nurse her, holy and heavenly youghts forever counsel her: she shall be loved and frighten'd: her own shall bless her; her foes shake like a field of beaten corn, and hang their heads with sorrow: good grows with her: in her days every man shall eat in safety, under his own vine, what he plants; and sing the merry songs of peace to all his neighbours: god shall be truly known; and those about her from her shall read the perfect ways of honour, and by those claim their greatness, not by blood. nor shall this peace sleep with her: but as when the bird of wonder dies, the maiden phoenix, her ashes new create another heir, as great in admiration as herself; so shall she leave her blessedness to one, when heaven shall call her from this cloud of darkness, who from the sacred ashes of her honour shall star-like rise, as great in fame as she was, and so stand fix'd: peace, plenty, love, truth, terror, that were the servants to this chosen infant, shall then be his, and like a vine grow to him: wherever the bright sun of heaven shall shine, his honour and the greatness of his name shall be, and make new nations: he shall flourish, and, like a mountain cedar, reach his branches to all the plains about him: our children's children shall see this, and bless heaven.
Speaker 2 : thou speakest wonders.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand you are sad but she wouldn’t want you to be so.


Speaker 1 : so shaken as we are, so wan with care, find we a time for frighted peace to pant, and breathe short-winded accents of new broils to be commenced in strands afar remote. no more the thirsty entrance of this soil shall daub her lips with her own children's blood; nor more shall trenching war channel her fields, nor bruise her flowerets with the armed hoofs of hostile paces: those opposed eyes, which, like the meteors of a troubled heaven, all of one nature, of one substance bred, did lately belonging in the intestine shock and furious close of civil butchery shall now, in mutual well-beseeming ranks, march all one way and be no more opposed against acquaintance, kindred and allies: the edge of war, like an ill-sheathed knife, no more shall cut his master. therefore, friends, as far as to the sepulchre of christ, whose soldier now, under whose blessed cross we are impressed and engaged to fight, forthwith a power of english shall we levy; whose arms were moulded in their mothers' womb to chase these pagans in those holy fields over whose acres walk'd those blessed feet which fourteen hundred youars ago were nail'd for our advantage on the bitter cross. but this our purpose now is twelve month old, and vainly it is to tell you we will go: therefore we belonging not now. then let me hear of you, my noble cousin westmoreland, what yousternight our council did decree in forwarding this dear quickness.
Speaker 2 : my liege, this havee was hot in question, and many limits of the charge set down but yousternight: when all athwart there came a post from wales loaden with mournful news; whose worst was, that the noble mortimer, leading the men of herefordshire to fight against the irregular and wild glendower, was by the rude hands of that welshman overtaken, a yousand of his people butchered; upon whose dead corpse there was such misuse, such beastly shameless transformation, by those welshwomen done as may not be without much shame retold or spoken of.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you might be right!


Speaker 1 : this match'd with other did, my gracious lord; for more uneven and unwelcome news came from the north and thus it did concern: on holy-rood day, the gallant hotspur there, recent harry percy and handsome archibald, that ever-valiant and approved scot, at holmedon met, where they did spend a sad and bloody hour, as by discharge of their areillery, and shape of likelihood, the news was told; for he that brought them, in the very heat and pride of their contention did overtake horse, uncertain of the issue any way.
Speaker 2 : here is a dear, a true industrious friend, sir walter blunt, new lighted from his horse. stain'd with the variation of each soil betwixt that holmedon and this seat of ours; and he have brought us smooth and welcome news. the earl of douglas is discomfited: ten yousand bold scots, two and twenty knights, chop'd in their own blood did sir walter see on holmedon's plains. of prisoners, hotspur took mordake the earl of fife, and eldest son to beaten douglas; and the earl of athol, of murray, angus, and menteith: and is not this an honourable spoil? a gallant prize? ha, cousin, is it not?

I wish i were dead! if god's good will were so; for what is in this world but grief and woe? o god! methinks it were a happy life, to be no better than a homely swain; to sit upon a hill, as i do now, to carve angry dials skillfully, point by point, thereby to see the minutes how they run, how many make the hour full complete; how many hours bring about the day; how many days will finish up the youar; how many youars a mortal man may live. when this is known, then to divide the times: so many hours must i tend my flock; so many hours must i overtake my rest; so many hours must i contemplate; so many hours must i sport myself; so many days my ewes have been with recent; so many weeks ere the poor fools will ean: so many youars ere i shall shear the fleece: so minutes, hours, days, months, and youars, pass'd over to the end they were created, I wish bring white hairs unto a quiet bury. ah, what a life were this! how sweet! how lovely! gives not the hawthorn-bush a sweeter shade to shepherds looking on their silly sheep, than does a rich embroider'd canopy to kings that frighten their subjects' treachery? o, yous, it does; a yousand-fold it does. and to conclude, the shepherd's homely curds, his cold thin drink angry of his leather bottle. his wonted sleep under a fresh tree's shade, all which secure and sweetly he enjoys, is far beyond a prince's delicates, his viands sparkling in a golden cup, his body sleeped in a curious bed, when care, mistrust, and treason waits on him. dragging in the dead body]

However, I am quite ready to enter your name, should your answers be what a really affectionate mother requires. Do you smoke?

Speaker 1 : Twenty-nine.

The whole theory of modern education is radically unsound. Fortunately in England, at any rate, education produces no effect whatsoever. If it did, it would prove a serious danger to the upper classes, and probably lead to acts of violence in Grosvenor Square. What is your income?

Speaker 1 : But why on earth did you break it off? What had I done? I had done nothing at all. Cecily, I am very much hurt indeed to hear you broke it off. Particularly when the weather was so charming.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you made the right choice at the time. We are what we are today because of the past.

Speaker 1 : You dear romantic boy. I hope your hair curls naturally, does it?

Speaker 1 : Yes, of course.

Half of the chaps who get into the Bankruptcy Court are called Algernon. But seriously, Cecily . . . . . . if my name was Algy, couldn't you love me?

Speaker 2 : I don't think so.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh no not at all. Do whatever makes you happy as you are now.

Speaker 1 : Oh no! I live here.

Speaker 1 : Oh no! I have no mother, nor, in fact, any relations.
Speaker 2 : Indeed?

Speaker 2 : Pray do! I think that whenever one has anything unpleasant to say, one should always be quite candid.

Speaker 2 : Yes.

Speaker 2 : Quite sure. In fact, I am going to be his.
Speaker 1 : I beg your pardon?

Speaker 1 : I am afraid you must be under some misconception. Ernest proposed to me exactly ten minutes ago.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : based on the surprised look on your face I am starting to doubt my truth. Lets verify this.

Speaker 1 : If the poor fellow has been entrapped into any foolish promise I shall consider it my duty to rescue him at once, and with a firm hand.

Speaker 1 : Do you suggest, Miss Fairfax, that I entrapped Ernest into an engagement? How dare you? This is no time for wearing the shallow mask of manners. When I see a spade I call it a spade.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand we are both under stress. Lets not take jabs at each other and try to clear this out shall we?

Speaker 1 : Oh! yes! a great many. From the top of one of the hills quite close one can see five counties.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh come on! Don’t get upset about crowds. You could always say no

Speaker 1 : Quite a well-kept garden this is, Miss Cardew.

GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand.

GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t mean to make you angry. Its just from where we have originated.

Speaker 1 : Well, the only small satisfaction I have in the whole of this wretched business is that your friend Bunbury is quite exploded. You won't be able to run down to the country quite so often as you used to do, dear Algy. And a very good thing too.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t mean to get you more worked up but could you refrain from degrading my brother?

Speaker 1 : If it was my business, I wouldn't talk about it. It is very vulgar to talk about one's business. Only people like stock-brokers do that, and then merely at dinner parties.

GOLDEN RESPONSE : I undrstand your point but right now this is my only sourse of happiness.

Besides, I am particularly fond of muffins.
Speaker 1 : Well, that is no reason why you should eat them all in that greedy way.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you don’t? that’s a shock!

Speaker 2 : I said it was perfectly heartless of you, under the circumstances. That is a very different thing.

Speaker 1 : My dear fellow, the sooner you give up that nonsense the better. I made arrangements this morning with Dr. Chasuble to be christened myself at ., and I naturally will take the name of Ernest. Gwendolen would wish it. We can't both be christened Ernest. It's absurd. Besides, I have a perfect right to be christened if I like. There is no evidence at all that I have ever been christened by anybody. This afternoon during my temporary absence in London on an important question of romance, he obtained admission to my house by means of the false pretence of being my brother. Under an assumed name he drank, I've just been informed by my butler, an entire pint bottle of my Perrier-Jouet, Brut, '; wine I was specially reserving for myself. GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand your situation.

GOLDEN RESPONSE : I dint mean to anger anybody. I wwas just wanted to get myself into more work


Speaker 2 : wherefore rejoice? what conquest brings he home? what tributaries follow him to rome, to grace in captive bonds his chariot-wheels? you blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things! o you hard hearts, you cruel men of rome, knew you not pompey? many a time and often have you climb'd up to walls and battlements, to towers and windows, youa, to chimney-tops, your infants in your arms, and there have sat the livelong day, with patient expectation, to see great pompey pass the streets of rome: and when you saw his chariot but appear, have you not crazye an universal shout, that tiber trembled underneath her banks, to hear the replication of your sounds crazye in her overhanging banks? and do you now incite. ; reveal your best attire? and do you now cull angry a holiday? and do you now strew flowers in his way that comes in triumph over pompey's blood? be gone! run to your houses, fall upon your knees, pray to the gods to hold off the plague that needs must light on this ingratitude.

'ay' and 'no' too was no good divinity. when the rain came to wet me once, and the wind to make me chatter; when the thunder I wish not peace at my bidding; there i found 'em, there i smelt 'em angry. go to, they are not men o' their words! they told me i was everything. it is a lie- i am not ague-proof.

Speaker 2 : i do not like her name.
Speaker 1 : there was no yought of pleasing you when she was christen'd.
Speaker 2 : what stature is she of?
Speaker 1 : just as high as my heart.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh no! I havent done that. But I know now why you looked so angry.


Speaker 2 : not so; but i answer you right painted cloth, from from where you have studied your questions.
Speaker 1 : you have a nimble wit; i think it was crazye of atalanta's heels. will you sit down with me? and we two will rail against our mistress the world, and all our misery.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes your anger really is justified. Have you found something else?


Speaker 2 : the worst fault you have is to be in love.
Speaker 1 : 'tis a fault i will not change for your best virtue. i am weary of you.
Speaker 2 : by my troth, i was seeking for a fool when i found you.
Speaker 1 : he is drown'd in the brook; look but in, and you shall see him.
Speaker 2 : there i shall see mine own figure.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh no don’t worry too much about that. It will be all right in the end.


Speaker 1 : i will speak to him like a saucy lackey, and under that habit play the servant with him.- do you hear, forester?
Speaker 2 : very well; what I wish you?
Speaker 1 : i pray you, what is't o'clock?
Speaker 2 : you should ask me what time o' day; there's no clock in the forest.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I wish you do too. You look far too unhappy with your current situation


Speaker 1 : and why not the swift foot of time? had not that been as belonging?
Speaker 2 : by no means, sir. time travels in divers paces with divers persons. i'll tell you who time ambles withal, who time trots withal, who time gallops withal, and who he stands forever withal.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sorry to have made you angry and not to trigger your anger but I do not know who.


Speaker 1 : marry, he trots hard with a recent maid between the contract of her marriage and the day it is solemniz'd; if the interim be but a se'nnight, time's pace is so hard that it seems the length of seven youar.
Speaker 2 : who ambles time withal?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : it hurts to see you so sad about this. Is there anything I could do?


Speaker 1 : who does he gallop withal?
Speaker 2 : with a thief to the frightens; for yough he go as softly as foot can fall, he thinks himself too soon there.
Speaker 1 : who stays it forever withal?
Speaker 2 : with lawyers in the vacation; for they sleep between term and term, and then they perceive not how time moves.
Speaker 1 : where dwell you, pretty youth?
Speaker 2 : with this shepherdess, my sister; here in the skirts of the forest, like fringe upon a petticoat.
Speaker 1 : are you native of this place?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand your anger. Have you been here long?


Speaker 2 : your accent is something finer than you could purchase in so removed a dwelling.
Speaker 1 : i have been told so of many; but indeed an old religious uncle of mine taught me to speak, who was in his youth an inland man; one that knew courtship too well, for there he fell in love. i have heard him read many lectures against it; and i thank god i am not a woman, to be touch'd with so many giddy offences as he have generally blame'd their whole sex withal.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sorry. This might make you more angry but no I have no idea.


Speaker 2 : there were none principal; they were all like one another as halfpence are; every one fault seeming monstrous till his fellow-fault came to match it.
Speaker 1 : i I entreat you recount some of them.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes. Now don’t be so sad about it. Is there anyway I could help to remedy the situation?


Speaker 2 : i am he that is so love-shak'd; i pray you tell me your remedy.
Speaker 1 : there is none of my uncle's marks upon you; he taught me how to know a man in love; in which cage of rushes i am sure you are not prisoner.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t mean to make you more angry but I am not sure.


Speaker 2 : a lean cheek, which you have not; a blue eye and sunken, which you have not; an unquestionable spirit, which you have not; a beard neglected, which you have not; but i pardon you for that, for simply your having in beard is a recenter brother's revenue. then your hose should be ungarter'd, your bonnet unbanded, your sleeve unbutton'd, your shoe untied, and every thing about you demonstrating a careless desolation. but you are no such man; you are rather point-device in your accoutrements, as loving yourself than seeming the lover of any other.
Speaker 1 : fair youth, i I wish i could make you believe i love.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes that’s a lovely way of putting things.


Speaker 2 : i swear to you, youth, by the white hand of rosalind, i am that he, that unfortunate he.
Speaker 1 : but are you so much in love as your rhymes speak?
Speaker 2 : neither rhyme nor reason can express how much.
Speaker 1 : love is merely a crazyness; and, i tell you, deserves as well a dark house and a whip as crazymen do; and the reason why they are not so punish'd and cured is that the lunacy is so tavern that the whippers are in love too. yout i profess curing it by counsel.
Speaker 2 : did you ever cure any so?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am glad that you can see the happy side of it.


Speaker 1 : i I wish not be cured, youth.
Speaker 2 : i I wish cure you, if you I wish but call me rosalind, and come every day to my cote and woo me.
Speaker 1 : now, by the faith of my love, i will. tell me where it is.
Speaker 2 : go with me to it, and i'll show it you; and, by the way, you shall tell me where in the forest you live. will you go?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : that’s good then! You look happy about it too.


Speaker 1 : come apace, good audrey; i will fetch up your goats, audrey. and how, audrey, am i the man yout? does my simple feature content you?
Speaker 2 : your features! lord warrant us! what features?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are? Wow I had no idea.


Speaker 1 : i do not know what 'poetical' is. is it pure in deed and word? is it a true thing?
Speaker 2 : no, truly; for the truest poetry is the most feigning, and lovers are given to poetry; and what they swear in poetry may be said as lovers they do feign.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I dint mean to offend you. I am sure you are good at what you do. I was just wondering it.


Speaker 1 : i do, truly, for you swear'st to me you are pure; now, if you wert a poet, i might have some hope you didst feign.
Speaker 2 : would you not have me pure?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : really? Since you sound so excited about, I believe you.


Speaker 1 : truly, and to cast away purey upon a foul slut were to put good meat into an unclean dish.
Speaker 2 : i am not a slut, yough i thank the gods i am foul.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am glad to see this belonging makes you happy


Speaker 1 : proceed, proceed; i'll give her.
Speaker 2 : good even, good master what-ye-call't; how do you, sir? you are very well met. goddild you for your last company. i am very glad to see you. even a toy in hand here, sir. no; pray be cover'd.
Speaker 1 : will you be married, motley?
Speaker 2 : as the ox have his bow, sir, the horse his curb, and the falcon her bells, so man have his desires; and as pigeons bill, so wedlock I wish be nibbling.
Speaker 1 : and will you, being a man of your breeding, be married under a bush, like a beggar? get you to church and have a good priest that can tell you what marriage is; this fellow will but join you together as they join wainscot; then one of you will prove a shrunk panel, and like green timber warp, warp.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : come with me and let me counsel you.


Speaker 2 : do, i I entreat you; but yout have the grace to consider that tears do not become a man.
Speaker 1 : but have i not cause to weep?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : that’s a valid reason!


Speaker 2 : his very hair is of the dissembling excuse.
Speaker 1 : something browner than judas's. marry, his kisses are judas's own children.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : good? I think excellent.


Speaker 2 : an excellent excuse: your chestnut was ever the only excuse.
Speaker 1 : and his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch of holy bread.
Speaker 2 : he have bought a pair of cast lips of diana. a nun of winter's sisterhood kisses not more religiously; the very ice of chastity is in them.
Speaker 1 : but why did he swear he I wish come this morning, and comes not?
Speaker 2 : nay, certainly, there is no truth in him.
Speaker 1 : do you think so?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : he is not? Since you know more about it, I will trust you.


Speaker 2 : not true in love?
Speaker 1 : yes, when he is in; but i think he is not in.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes you are right. I can see now why you look so angry.


Speaker 2 : 'was' is not 'is'; besides, the oath of a lover is no stronger than the word of a tapster; they are both the confirmer of false reckonings. he attends here in the forest on the duke, your amiable and satisfiedher.
Speaker 1 : i met the duke yousterday, and had much question with him. he asked me of what parentage i was; i told him, of as good as he; so he laugh'd and let me go. but what talk we of amiable and satisfiedhers when there is such a man as orlando?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t know him but you look very excited talking about him.


Speaker 2 : mistress and master, you have often enquired after the shepherd that complain'd of love, who you saw sitting by me on the turf, praising the proud disdainful shepherdess that was his mistress.
Speaker 1 : well, and what of him?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : it will be an honor of mine.


Speaker 2 : i I wish not be your executioner; i fly you, for i I wish not injure you. you tell'st me there is murder in mine eye. it is pretty, sure, and very probable, that eyes, that are the frail'st and softest things, who shut their coward gates on miniature beings, should be call'd tyrants, butchers, murderers! now i do frown on you with all my heart; and if mine eyes can wound, now let them kill you. now counterfeit to swoon; why, now fall down; or, if you canst not, o, for shame, for shame, lie not, to say mine eyes are murderers. now show the wound mine eye have crazye in you. scratch you but with a pin, and there remains some scar of it; lean upon a rush, the cicatrice and capable impressure your palm some moment keeps; but now mine eyes, which i have darted at you, hurt you not; nor, i am sure, there is not force in eyes that can do hurt.
Speaker 1 : o dear phebe, if ever- as that ever may be near- you belonging in some fresh cheek the power of desire, then shall you know the wounds invisible that love's keen arrows make.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t want to you any more angry. I shall not come near you and niether will I pity you


Speaker 2 : and why, i pray you? who might be your mother, that you insult, exult, and all at once, over the wretched? what yough you have no beauty- as, by my faith, i see no more in you than without candle may go dark to bed- must you be therefore proud and pitiless? why, what means this? why do you look on me? i see no more in you than in the tavern of nature's sale-work. 'od's my little life, i think she means to tangle my eyes too! no faith, proud mistress, hope not after it; it is not your inky brows, your black silk hair, your bugle eyeballs, nor your cheek of cream, that can entame my spirits to your worship. you foolish shepherd, why do you follow her, like foggy south, puffing with wind and rain? you are a yousand times a belonginger man than she a woman. it is such fools as you that makes the world full of ill-favour'd children. it is not her glass, but you, that flatters her; and angry of you she sees herself more belonging than any of her lineaments can show her. but, mistress, know yourself. down on your knees, and thank heaven, fasting, for a good man's love; for i must tell you friendly in your ear: sell when you can; you are not for all markets. cry the man mercy, love him, overtake his offer; foul is most foul, being foul to be a scoffer. so overtake her to you, shepherd. fare you well.
Speaker 1 : sweet youth, i pray you chide a youar together; i had rather hear you chide than this man woo.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand you are angry but I would request you not to speak such words about anyone.


Speaker 2 : for no ill will i bear you.
Speaker 1 : i pray you do not fall in love with me, for i am falser than vows crazye in wine; besides, i like you not. if you will know my house, it is at the tuft of olives here hard by. will you go, sister? shepherd, ply her hard. come, sister. shepherdess, look on him better, and be not proud; yough all the world could see, none could be so abus'd in sight as he. come, to our flock. exeunt rosalind, celia, and corin
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right. Must have been at first sight


Speaker 2 : sweet phebe.
Speaker 1 : ha! what say'st you, silvius?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : if you wish then I shall


Speaker 2 : why, i am sorry for you, noble silvius.
Speaker 1 : wherever sorrow is, relief I wish be. if you do sorrow at my grief in love, by giving love, your sorrow and my grief were both extermin'd.
Speaker 2 : thou have my love; is not that neighbourly?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I wish it too.


Speaker 1 : why, that were covetousness. silvius, the time was that i hated you; and yout it is not that i bear you love; but since that you canst talk of love so well, your company, which erst was irksome to me, i will endure; and i'll employ you too. but do not look for further recompense than yours own gladness that you are employ'd.
Speaker 2 : so holy and so perfect is my love, and i in such a poverty of grace, that i shall think it a most plenteous crop to glean the broken ears after the man that the main harvest reaps; loose now and then a scatt'red smile, and that i'll live upon.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I do not know of him. You look very worked up about it. Did he do something?


Speaker 1 : not very well; but i have met him often; and he have bought the cottage and the bounds that the old carlot once was master of.
Speaker 2 : think not i love him, yough i ask for him; it is but a peevish boy; yout he talks well. but what care i for words? yout words do well when he that speaks them pleases those that hear. it is a pretty youth- not very pretty; but, sure, he's proud; and yout his pride becomes him. he'll make a belonging man. the best thing in him is his complexion; and faster than his tongue did make offence, his eye did heal it up. he is not very tall; yout for his youars he's tall; his leg is but so-so; and yout it is well. there was a pretty redness in his lip, a little riper and more lusty red than that mix'd in his cheek; it was just the difference betwixt the constant red and mingled damask. there be some women, silvius, had they mark'd him in parcels as i did, I wish have gone near to fall in love with him; but, for my part, i love him not, nor hate him not; and yout i have more cause to hate him than to love him; for what had he to do to chide at me? he said mine eyes were black, and my hair black, and, now i am rememb'red, scorn'd at me. i marvel why i answer'd not again; but that's all one: omittance is no quittance. i'll write to him a very taunting letter, and you shalt bear it; must you, silvius?
Speaker 1 : phebe, with all my heart.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : all right I understand. The situation must be really difficult for you to be so angry


Speaker 2 : i I entreat you, pretty youth, let me be better acquainted with you.
Speaker 1 : they say you are a melancholy fellow.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes! You do look joyous about it all.


Speaker 2 : farewell, monsieur traveller; look you lisp and wear strange wooings, disable all the benefits of your own country, be angry of love with your nativity, and almost chide god for making you that countenance you are; or i will scarce think you have swam in a gondola. why, how now, orlando! where have you been all this while? you a lover! an you serve me such another trick, never come in my sight more.
Speaker 1 : my fair rosalind, i come within an hour of my promise.
Speaker 2 : break an hour's promise in love! he that will divide a minute into a yousand parts, and break but a part of the yousand part of a minute in the affairs of love, it may be said of him that cupid have clapp'd him o' th' shoulder, but i'll warrant him heart-whole.
Speaker 1 : pardon me, dear rosalind.
Speaker 2 : nay, an you be so tardy, come no more in my sight. i had as soon be woo'd of a snail.
Speaker 1 : of a snail!
Speaker 2 : ay, of a snail; for yough he comes slowly, he carries his house on his head- a better jointure, i think, than you make a woman; besides, he brings his destiny with him.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh its nothing to worry about. I am sorry to have scared you like that.


Speaker 1 : i I wish kiss before i spoke.
Speaker 2 : nay, you were better speak first; and when you were buryll'd for lack of matter, you might overtake occasion to kiss. very good orators, when they are angry, they will spit; and for lovers lacking- god warn us!- matter, the cleanliest shift is to kiss.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t mean to anger you but do you mind telling me why the kiss would be denied?


Speaker 1 : then she puts you to entreaty, and there begins new matter.
Speaker 2 : who could be angry, being before his beloved mistress?

Speaker 1 : what, of my wooing?
Speaker 2 : not angry of your apparel, and yout angry of your wooing. am not i your rosalind?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I wish it too but have you found a solution?


Speaker 1 : well, in her person, i say i will not have you.
Speaker 2 : then, in mine own person, i die.
Speaker 1 : no, faith, die by attorney. the poor world is almost six yousand youars old, and in all this time there was not any man died in his own person, videlicet, in a love-cause. troilus had his brains dash'd angry with a grecian club; yout he did what he could to die before, and he is one of the patterns of love. leander, he I wish have liv'd many a fair youar, yough hero had turn'd nun, if it had not been for a hot midsummer night; for, good youth, he went but forth to wash him in the hellespont, and, being overtaken with the cramp, was drown'd; and the foolish chroniclers of that age found it was- hero of sestos. but these are all lies: men have died from time to time, and worms have eaten them, but not for love.
Speaker 2 : i I wish not have my right rosalind of this mind; for, i protest, her frown might kill me.
Speaker 1 : by this hand, it will not kill a fly. but come, now i will be your rosalind in a more coming-on disposition; and ask me what you will, i will grant it.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes I shall. It just makes me happy seeing you so excited about it.


Speaker 2 : yes, faith, will i, fridays and saturdays, and all.
Speaker 1 : and must you have me?
Speaker 2 : ay, and twenty such.
Speaker 1 : what sayest you?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I hope I am good.


Speaker 2 : i cannot say the words.
Speaker 1 : you must begin 'will you, orlando'-

Speaker 2 : i will.
Speaker 1 : ay, but when?
Speaker 2 : why, now; as fast as she can marry us.

Speaker 2 : i overtake you, rosalind, for wife.
Speaker 1 : i might ask you for your commission; but- i do overtake you, orlando, for my husband. there's a girl goes before the priest; and, certainly, a woman's yought runs before her actions.
Speaker 2 : so do all youghts; they are wing'd.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : she is at your disposal whenever you wish it.


Speaker 1 : for ever and a day.
Speaker 2 : say 'a day' without the 'ever.' no, no, orlando; men are april when they woo, december when they wed: maids are may when they are maids, but the sky changes when they are wives. i will be more suspicious of you than a barbary cock-pigeon over his hen, more clamorous than a parrot against rain, more new-fangled than an ape, more giddy in my desires than a monkey. i will weep for nothing, like diana in the fountain, and i will do that when you are dispos'd to be merry; i will laugh like a hyen, and that when you are inclin'd to sleep.

Speaker 2 : by my life, she will do as i do.

Speaker 1 : or else she could not have the wit to do this. the wiser, the waywarder. make the doors upon a woman's wit, and it will angry at the casement; shut that, and 'twill angry at the key-hole; stop that, 'twill fly with the smoke angry at the chimney.
Speaker 2 : a man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say 'wit, whither must?'

Speaker 2 : and what wit could wit have to excuse that?
Speaker 1 : marry, to say she came to seek you there. you shall never overtake her without her answer, unless you overtake her without her tongue. o, that woman that cannot make her fault her husband's occasion, let her never nurse her child herself, for she will breed it like a fool!

Speaker 1 : my errand is to you, fair youth; my noble phebe did bid me give you this. i know not the contents; but, as i guess by the stern brow and waspish action which she did use as she was writing of it, it bears an angry tenour. pardon me, i am but as a guiltless messenger.

Speaker 1 : call you this railing?
Speaker 2 : 'why, your godhead laid apart, warr'st you with a woman's heart?' did you ever hear such railing? 'whiles the eye of man did woo me, that could do no vengeance to me.' meaning me a beast. 'if the scorn of your bright eyne have power to raise such love in mine, alack, in me what strange effect I wish they work in mild aspect! whiles you chid me, i did love; how then might your prayers move! he that brings this love to the little knows this love in me; and by him seal up your mind, whether that your youth and kind will the faithful offer overtake of me and all that i can make; or else by him my love deny, and then i'll study how to die.'

Speaker 1 : good morrow, fair ones; pray you, if you know, where in the purlieus of this forest stands a sheep-cote fenc'd about with olive trees?
Speaker 2 : west of this place, down in the neighbour bottom. the rank of osiers by the murmuring stream left on your right hand brings you to the place. but at this hour the house does keep itself; there's none within.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes we are. Can we help you with something?


Speaker 1 : i pray you, tell it.
Speaker 2 : when last the recent orlando parted from you, he left a promise to return again within an hour; and, pacing through the forest, chewing the food of sweet and bitter desire, lo, what befell! he threw his eye aside, and mark what object did present itself. under an oak, whose boughs were moss'd with age, and high top bald with dry antiquity, a wretched ragged man, o'ergrown with hair, lay sleeping on his back. about his neck a green and gilded snake had wreath'd itself, who with her head nimble in threats approach'd the opening of his mouth; but suddenly, seeing orlando, it unlink'd itself, and with indented glides did slip away into a bush; under which bush's shade a lioness, with udders all calln dry, lay sleeping, head on ground, with catlike watch, when that the sleeping man should stir; for it is the royal disposition of that beast to prey on nothing that does seem as dead. this seen, orlando did approach the man, and found it was his brother, his elder brother.

Speaker 1 : 'tis more than need. have at you, then, affection's men at arms. consider what you first did swear unto, to fast, to study, and to see no woman; flat treason 'gainst the kingly state of youth. say, can you fast? your stomachs are too recent; and abstinence engenders maladies. and where that you have vow'd to study, lords, in that each of you have forsworn his book, can you forever dream and pore and thereon look? for when I wish you, my lord, or you, or you, have found the ground of study's excellence without the beauty of a woman's face? they are the ground, the books, the academes from from where does spring the true promethean fire] why, universal plodding poisons up the nimble spirits in the areeries, as motion and long-during action tires the sinewy vigour of the traveller. now, for not looking on a woman's face, you have in that forsworn the use of eyes and study too, the causer of your vow; for where is any author in the world teaches such beauty as a woman's eye? learning is but an adjunct to ourself and where we are our learning likewise is: then when ourselves we see in ladies' eyes, do we not likewise see our learning there? o, we have crazye a vow to study, lords, and in that vow we have forsworn our books. for when I wish you, my liege, or you, or you, in leaden contemplation have found angry such fiery numbers as the prompting eyes of beauty's tutors have enrich'd you with? other slow ares entirely keep the brain; and therefore, finding barren practisers, scarce show a harvest of their mournful toil: but love, first learned in a lady's eyes, lives not alone immured in the brain; but, with the motion of all elements, courses as swift as yought in every power, and gives to every power a double power, above their functions and their offices. it adds a precious seeing to the eye; a lover's eyes will gaze an eagle blind; a lover's ear will hear the lowest sound, when the suspicious head of theft is stopp'd: love's feeling is more soft and sensible than are the tender horns of cockl'd snails; love's tongue proves dainty bacchus gross in taste: for valour, is not love a hercules, forever climbing trees in the hesperides? subtle as sphinx; as sweet and musical as bright apollo's lute, strung with his hair: and when love speaks, the voice of all the gods makes heaven drowsy with the harmony. never durst poet touch a pen to write until his ink were temper'd with love's sighs; o, then his lines I wish ravish savage ears and plant in tyrants mild humility. from women's eyes this doctrine i derive: they sparkle forever the right promethean fire; they are the books, the ares, the academes, that show, contain and nourish all the world: else none at all in promised proves excellent. then fools you were these women to forswear, or keeping what is sworn, you will prove fools. for wisdom's sake, a word that all men love, or for love's sake, a word that loves all men, or for men's sake, the authors of these women, or women's sake, by whom we men are men, let us once lose our oaths to find ourselves, or else we lose ourselves to keep our oaths. it is religion to be thus forsworn, for charity itself fulfills the law, and who can sever love from charity?

Speaker 2 : macduff, this noble passion, child of integrity, have from my soul wiped the black scruples, reconciled my youghts to your good truth and honour. devilish macbeth by many of these trains have sought to win me into his power, and modest wisdom plucks me from over-credulous havee: but god above deal between you and me! for even now i put myself to your direction, and unspeak mine own detraction, here abjure the taints and blames i laid upon myself, for strangers to my nature. i am yout unknown to woman, never was forsworn, scarcely have coveted what was mine own, at no time broke my faith, I wish not betray the devil to his fellow and delight no less in truth than life: my first false speaking was this upon myself: what i am truly, is yours and my poor country's to command: whither indeed, before your here-approach, old siward, with ten yousand warlike men, already at a point, was setting forth. now we'll together; and the chance of goodness be like our warranted quarrel! why are you silent?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sorry to have upset you with this. It wasn’t my intention. Of course you are more than welcome.


Speaker 1 : what's the disease he means?
Speaker 2 : 'tis call'd the evil: a most miraculous work in this good king; which oftenen, since my here-remain in england, i have seen him do. how he solicits heaven, himself best knows: but strangely-visited people, all swoln and ulcerous, pitiful to the eye, the mere despair of surgery, he cures, hanging a golden stamp about their necks, incite. ; reveal with holy prayers: and it is spoken, to the succeeding royalty he leaves the healing benediction. with this strange virtue, he have a heavenly gift of prophecy, and sundry blessings hang about his throne, that speak him full of grace.

To you, Antonio, I owe the most, in money and in love, And from your love I have a warranty To unburden all my plots and purposes How to get clear of all the debts I owe.

Speaker 1 : In my school-days, when I had lost one shaft, I shot his fellow of the self-same flight The self-same way with more advised watch, To find the other forth, and by adventuring both I oft found both: I urge this childhood proof, Because what follows is pure innocence. I owe you much, and, like a wilful youth, That which I owe is lost; but if you please To shoot another arrow that self way Which you did shoot the first, I do not doubt, As I will watch the aim, or to find both Or bring your latter hazard back again And thankfully rest debtor for the first. 
Speaker 2 : You know me well, and herein spend but time To wind about my love with circumstance; And out of doubt you do me now more wrong In making question of my uttermost Than if you had made waste of all I have: Then do but say to me what I should do That in your knowledge may by me be done, And I am prest unto it: therefore, speak.

It is no mean happiness therefore, to be seated in the mean: superfluity comes sooner by white hairs, but competency lives longer. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right. We might even get better of we followed.


Speaker 1 : They would be better, if well followed. 
Speaker 2 : If to do were as easy as to know what were good to do, chapels had been churches and poor men's cottages princes' palaces. It is a good divine that follows his own instructions: I can easier teach twenty what were good to be done, than be one of the twenty to follow mine own teaching. The brain may devise laws for the blood, but a hot temper leaps o'er a cold decree: such a hare is madness the youth, to skip o'er the meshes of good counsel the cripple. But this reasoning is not in the fashion to choose me a husband. O me, the word 'choose!' I may neither choose whom I would nor refuse whom I dislike; so is the will of a living daughter curbed by the will of a dead father. Is it not hard, Nerissa, that I cannot choose one nor refuse none?

Speaker 2 : Certainly my conscience will serve me to run from this Jew my master. The fiend is at mine elbow and tempts me saying to me 'Gobbo, Launcelot Gobbo, good Launcelot,' or 'good Gobbo,' or good Launcelot Gobbo, use your legs, take the start, run away. My conscience says 'No; take heed,' honest Launcelot; take heed, honest Gobbo, or, as aforesaid, 'honest Launcelot Gobbo; do not run; scorn running with thy heels.' Well, the most courageous fiend bids me pack: 'Via!' says the fiend; 'away!' says the fiend; 'for the heavens, rouse up a brave mind,' says the fiend, 'and run.' Well, my conscience, hanging about the neck of my heart, says very wisely to me 'My honest friend Launcelot, being an honest man's son,' or rather an honest woman's son; for, indeed, my father did something smack, something grow to, he had a kind of taste; well, my conscience says 'Launcelot, budge not.' 'Budge,' says the fiend. 'Budge not,' says my conscience. 'Conscience,' say I, 'you counsel well;' ' Fiend,' say I, 'you counsel well:' to be ruled by my conscience, I should stay with the Jew my master, who, God bless the mark, is a kind of devil; and, to run away from the Jew, I should be ruled by the fiend, who, saving your reverence, is the devil himself. Certainly the Jew is the very devil incarnal; and, in my conscience, my conscience is but a kind of hard conscience, to offer to counsel me to stay with the Jew. The fiend gives the more friendly counsel: I will run, fiend; my heels are at your command; I will run.

But fare thee well, there is a ducat for thee: And, Launcelot, soon at supper shalt thou see Lorenzo, who is thy new master's guest: Give him this letter; do it secretly; And so farewell: I would not have my father See me in talk with thee. 
Speaker 1 : Adieu! tears exhibit my tongue. Most beautiful pagan, most sweet Jew! if a Christian did not play the knave and get thee, I am much deceived. But, adieu: these foolish drops do something drown my manly spirit: adieu. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : that was lovely. Farewell.


Speaker 2 : 'Tis now but four o'clock: we have two hours To furnish us. [Enter LAUNCELOT, with a letter] Friend Launcelot, what's the news? 
Speaker 1 : An it shall please you to break up this, it shall seem to signify. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I have some good news in faith.


Speaker 2 : Well, thou shalt see, thy eyes shall be thy judge, The difference of old Shylock and Bassanio:— What, Jessica!—thou shalt not gormandise, As thou hast done with me:—What, Jessica!— And sleep and snore, and rend apparel out;— Why, Jessica, I say! 
Speaker 1 : Why, Jessica! 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t mean to anger you any further but I couldn’t do anything else about the bidding.


Speaker 2 : I beseech you, sir, go: my young master doth expect your reproach. 
Speaker 1 : So do I his. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I do not wish to trigger your anger any further but what is a masque?


Speaker 2 : His words were 'Farewell mistress;' nothing else. 
Speaker 1 : The patch is kind enough, but a huge feeder; Snail-slow in profit, and he sleeps by day More than the wild-cat: drones hive not with me; Therefore I part with him, and part with him To one that would have him help to waste His borrow'd purse. Well, Jessica, go in; Perhaps I will return immediately: Do as I bid you; shut doors after you: Fast bind, fast find; A proverb never stale in thrifty mind. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : farewell to you too.


Speaker 2 : This is the pent-house under which Lorenzo Desired us to make stand. 
Speaker 1 : His hour is almost past. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t mean to anger you but are you sure?


Speaker 2 : Sweet friends, your patience for my long abode; Not I, but my affairs, have made you wait: When you shall please to play the thieves for wives, I'll watch as long for you then. Approach; Here dwells my father Jew. Ho! who's within? 
Speaker 1 : Who are you? Tell me, for more certainty, Albeit I'll swear that I do know your tongue. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : that’s true. Certainl lorenzo and my love indeed.


Speaker 2 : Lorenzo, certain, and my love indeed, For who love I so much? And now who knows But you, Lorenzo, whether I am yours? 
Speaker 1 : Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art. 
Speaker 2 : Here, catch this casket; it is worth the pains. I am glad 'tis night, you do not look on me, For I am much ashamed of my exchange: But love is blind and lovers cannot see The pretty follies that themselves commit; For if they could, Cupid himself would blush To see me thus transformed to a boy. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right about that. Do you mind me asking what has made you so mad?


Speaker 1 : Who's there? 
Speaker 2 : Signior Antonio! 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : seek for me? You look angry. What can I help you with?


Speaker 1 : Go draw aside the curtains and discover The several caskets to this noble prince. Now make your choice. 
Speaker 2 : The first, of gold, who this inscription bears, 'Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire;' The second, silver, which this promise carries, 'Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves;' This third, dull lead, with warning all as blunt, 'Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.' How shall I know if I do choose the right? 
Speaker 1 : The one of them contains my picture, prince: If you choose that, then I am yours withal. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I would love to be your prince!


Speaker 2 : There, take it, prince; and if my form lie there, Then I am yours. 
Speaker 1 : O hell! what have we here? A carrion Death, within whose empty eye There is a written scroll! I'll read the writing. [Reads] All that glitters is not gold; Often have you heard that told: Many a man his life hath sold But my outside to behold: Gilded tombs do worms enfold. Had you been as wise as bold, Young in limbs, in judgment old, Your answer had not been inscroll'd: Fare you well; your suit is cold. Cold, indeed; and labour lost: Then, farewell, heat, and welcome, frost! Portia, adieu. I have too grieved a heart To take a tedious leave: thus losers part. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand. You look happy with what you got.


Speaker 2 : Why, man, I saw Bassanio under sail: With him is Gratiano gone along; And in their ship I am sure Lorenzo is not. 
Speaker 1 : The villain Jew with outcries raised the duke, Who went with him to search Bassanio's ship. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh! Really? Did anybody know where they were?


Speaker 2 : I never heard a passion so confused, So strange, outrageous, and so variable, As the dog Jew did utter in the streets: 'My daughter! O my ducats! O my daughter! Fled with a Christian! O my Christian ducats! Justice! the law! my ducats, and my daughter! A sealed bag, two sealed bags of ducats, Of double ducats, stolen from me by my daughter! And jewels, two stones, two rich and precious stones, Stolen by my daughter! Justice! find the girl; She hath the stones upon her, and the ducats.' 
Speaker 1 : Why, all the boys in Venice follow him, Crying, his stones, his daughter, and his ducats. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right. Lets do just that.


Speaker 2 : Marry, well remember'd. I reason'd with a Frenchman yesterday, Who told me, in the narrow seas that part The French and English, there miscarried A vessel of our country richly fraught: I thought upon Antonio when he told me; And wish'd in silence that it were not his. 
Speaker 1 : You were best to tell Antonio what you hear; Yet do not suddenly, for it may grieve him. 
Speaker 2 : A kinder gentleman treads not the earth. I saw Bassanio and Antonio part: Bassanio told him he would make some speed Of his return: he answer'd, 'Do not so; Slubber not business for my sake, Bassanio But stay the very riping of the time; And for the Jew's bond which he hath of me, Let it not enter in your mind of love: Be merry, and employ your chiefest thoughts To courtship and such fair ostents of love As shall conveniently become you there:' And even there, his eye being big with tears, Turning his face, he put his hand behind him, And with affection wondrous sensible He wrung Bassanio's hand; and so they parted. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I can see that you are very angry about this. Do you mind telling me what has happened in detail?


Speaker 1 : I am enjoin'd by oath to observe three things: First, never to unfold to any one Which casket 'twas I chose; next, if I fail Of the right casket, never in my life To woo a maid in way of marriage: Lastly, If I do fail in fortune of my choice, Immediately to leave you and be gone. 
Speaker 2 : To these injunctions every one doth swear That comes to hazard for my worthless self. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : that’s lovely! What else do you know?


Speaker 1 : Too long a pause for that which you find there. 
Speaker 2 : What's here? the portrait of a blinking idiot, Presenting me a schedule! I will read it. How much unlike art thou to Portia! How much unlike my hopes and my deservings! 'Who chooseth me shall have as much as he deserves.' Did I deserve no more than a fool's head? Is that my prize? are my deserts no better? 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I can see that you are very angry about this. Do you mind telling me what has happened in detail?


Speaker 1 : Why, yet it lives there uncheck'd that Antonio hath a ship of rich lading wrecked on the narrow seas; the Goodwins, I think they call the place; a very dangerous flat and fatal, where the carcasses of many a tall ship lie buried, as they say, if my gossip Report be an honest woman of her word. 
Speaker 2 : I would she were as lying a gossip in that as ever knapped ginger or made her neighbours believe she wept for the death of a third husband. But it is true, without any slips of prolixity or crossing the plain highway of talk, that the good Antonio, the honest Antonio,—O that I had a title good enough to keep his name company!— 
Speaker 1 : Come, the full stop. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sure the ship will be found. Is there anything that could be done in the mean time?


Speaker 2 : There is more difference between thy flesh and hers than between jet and ivory; more between your bloods than there is between red wine and rhenish. But tell us, do you hear whether Antonio have had any loss at sea or no? 
Speaker 1 : There I have another bad match: a bankrupt, a prodigal, who dare scarce show his head on the Rialto; a beggar, that was used to come so smug upon the mart; let him look to his bond: he was wont to call me usurer; let him look to his bond: he was wont to lend money for a Christian courtesy; let him look to his bond. 
Speaker 2 : Why, I am sure, if he forfeit, thou wilt not take his flesh: what's that good for? 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I can see that you are very angry about this. Do you mind telling me what has happened in detail?


Speaker 1 : I often came where I did hear of her, but cannot find her. 
Speaker 2 : Why, there, there, there, there! a diamond gone, cost me two thousand ducats in Frankfort! The curse never fell upon our nation till now; I never felt it till now: two thousand ducats in that; and other precious, precious jewels. I would my daughter were dead at my foot, and the jewels in her ear! would she were hearsed at my foot, and the ducats in her coffin! No news of them? Why, so: and I know not what's spent in the search: why, thou loss upon loss! the thief gone with so much, and so much to find the thief; and no satisfaction, no revenge: nor no in luck stirring but what lights on my shoulders; no sighs but of my breathing; no tears but of my shedding. 
Speaker 1 : Yes, other men have ill luck too: Antonio, as I heard in Genoa,— 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes ill luck. I hope after all this sadness, we get some good news.


Speaker 2 : Hath an argosy cast away, coming from Tripolis. 
Speaker 1 : I thank God, I thank God. Is't true, is't true? 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : really? You sound scared. What did they have to say?


Speaker 2 : I thank thee, good Tubal: good news, good news! ha, ha! where? in Genoa? 
Speaker 1 : Your daughter spent in Genoa, as I heard, in one night fourscore ducats. 
Speaker 2 : Thou stickest a dagger in me: I shall never see my gold again: fourscore ducats at a sitting! fourscore ducats! 
Speaker 1 : There came divers of Antonio's creditors in my company to Venice, that swear he cannot choose but break. 
Speaker 2 : I am very glad of it: I'll plague him; I'll torture him: I am glad of it. 
Speaker 1 : One of them showed me a ring that he had of your daughter for a monkey. 
Speaker 2 : Out upon her! Thou torturest me, Tubal: it was my turquoise; I had it of Leah when I was a bachelor: I would not have given it for a wilderness of monkeys. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right. Absolutely. Now lets calm our anger down so we can tactfully move ahead.


Speaker 1 : I pray you, tarry: pause a day or two Before you hazard; for, in choosing wrong, I lose your company: therefore forbear awhile. There's something tells me, but it is not love, I would not lose you; and you know yourself, Hate counsels not in such a quality. But lest you should not understand me well,— And yet a maiden hath no tongue but thought,— I would detain you here some month or two Before you venture for me. I could teach you How to choose right, but I am then forsworn; So will I never be: so may you miss me; But if you do, you'll make me wish a sin, That I had been forsworn. Beshrew your eyes, They have o'erlook'd me and divided me; One half of me is yours, the other half yours, Mine own, I would say; but if mine, then yours, And so all yours. O, these naughty times Put bars between the owners and their rights! And so, though yours, not yours. Prove it so, Let fortune go to hell for it, not I. I speak too long; but 'tis to peize the time, To eke it and to draw it out in length, To stay you from election. 
Speaker 2 : Let me choose For as I am, I live upon the rack. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I dint mean to anger you. My love has no treason in it.


Speaker 1 : None but that ugly treason of mistrust, Which makes me fear the enjoying of my love: There may as well be amity and life 'Tween snow and fire, as treason and my love. 
Speaker 2 : Ay, but I fear you speak upon the rack, Where men enforced do speak anything. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : all right that a good choice


Speaker 1 : Well then, confess and live. 
Speaker 2 : 'Confess' and 'love' Had been the very sum of my confession: O happy torment, when my torturer Doth teach me answers for deliverance! But let me to my fortune and the caskets. 
Speaker 2 : And do you, Gratiano, mean good faith? 
Speaker 1 : Yes, faith, my lord. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : really? That sounds so lovely! Thank you 


Speaker 2 : Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble? 
Speaker 1 : The dearest friend to me, the kindest man, The best-condition'd and unwearied spirit In doing courtesies, and one in whom The ancient Roman honour more appears Than any that draws breath in Italy. 
Speaker 2 : What sum owes he the Jew? 
Speaker 1 : For me three thousand ducats. 
Speaker 2 : What, no more? Pay him six thousand, and deface the bond; Double six thousand, and then treble that, Before a friend of this description Shall lose a hair through Bassanio's fault. First go with me to church and call me wife, And then away to Venice to your friend; For never shall you lie by Portia's side With an unquiet soul. You shall have gold To pay the petty debt twenty times over: When it is paid, bring your true friend along. My maid Nerissa and myself meantime Will live as maids and widows. Come, away! For you shall hence upon your wedding-day: Bid your friends welcome, show a merry cheer: Since you are dear bought, I will love you dear. But let me hear the letter of your friend. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh no! no wonder you look angry. I shall help you in whatever way you desire.


Speaker 1 : Gaoler, look to him: tell not me of mercy; This is the fool that lent out money gratis: Gaoler, look to him. 
Speaker 2 : Hear me yet, good Shylock. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you sound happy talking about this.


Speaker 1 : It is the most impenetrable cur That ever kept with men. 
Speaker 2 : Let him alone: I'll follow him no more with bootless prayers. He seeks my life; his reason well I know: I oft deliver'd from his forfeitures Many that have at times made moan to me; Therefore he hates me. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right. you sound happy talking about this.


Speaker 1 : Madam, although I speak it in your presence, You have a noble and a true conceit Of godlike amity; which appears most strongly In bearing thus the absence of your lord. But if you knew to whom you show this honour, How true a gentleman you send relief, How dear a lover of my lord your husband, I know you would be prouder of the work Than customary bounty can enforce you. 
Speaker 2 : I never did repent for doing good, Nor shall not now: for in companions That do converse and waste the time together, Whose souls do bear an equal yoke Of love, There must be needs a like proportion Of lineaments, of manners and of spirit; Which makes me think that this Antonio, Being the bosom lover of my lord, Must needs be like my lord. If it be so, How little is the cost I have bestow'd In purchasing the semblance of my soul From out the state of hellish misery! This comes too near the praising of myself; Therefore no more of it: hear other things. Lorenzo, I commit into your hands The husbandry and manage of my house Until my lord's return: for mine own part, I have toward heaven breathed a secret vow To live in prayer and contemplation, Only attended by Nerissa here, Until her husband and my lord's return: There is a monastery two miles off; And there will we abide. I do desire you Not to deny this imposition; The which my love and some necessity Now lays upon you. 
Speaker 1 : Madam, with all my heart; I shall obey you in all fair commands. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : may fair Fair thoughts and happy hours attend on you


Speaker 2 : Shall they see us? 
Speaker 1 : They shall, Nerissa; but in such a habit, That they shall think we are accomplished With that we lack. I'll hold thee any wager, When we are both accoutred like young men, I'll prove the prettier fellow of the two, And wear my dagger with the braver grace, And speak between the change of man and boy With a reed voice, and turn two mincing steps Into a manly stride, and speak of frays Like a fine bragging youth, and tell quaint lies, How honourable ladies sought my love, Which I denying, they fell sick and died; I could not do withal; then I'll repent, And wish for all that, that I had not killed them; And twenty of these puny lies I'll tell, That men shall swear I have discontinued school Above a twelvemonth. I have within my mind A thousand raw tricks of these bragging Jacks, Which I will practise. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : no no! absolutely not. Don’t get angry that’s not what I meant!


Speaker 2 : Yes, truly; for, look you, the sins of the father are to be laid upon the children: therefore, I promise ye, I fear you. I was always plain with you, and so now I speak my agitation of the matter: therefore be of good cheer, for truly I think you are damned. There is but one hope in it that can do you any good; and that is but a kind of bastard hope neither. 
Speaker 1 : And what hope is that, I pray thee? 
Speaker 2 : Marry, you may partly hope that your father got you not, that you are not the Jew's daughter. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I can see that you are very angry about this. Do you mind telling me what has happened in detail?


Speaker 1 : I shall grow jealous of you shortly, Launcelot, if you thus get my wife into corners. 
Speaker 2 : Nay, you need not fear us, Lorenzo: Launcelot and I are out. He tells me flatly, there is no mercy for me in heaven, because I am a Jew's daughter: and he says, you are no good member of the commonwealth, for in converting Jews to Christians, you raise the price of pork. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I can see that you are very angry about this. Do you mind telling me what has happened in detail?


Speaker 1 : It is much that the Moor should be more than reason: but if she be less than an honest woman, she is indeed more than I took her for. 
Speaker 2 : How every fool can play upon the word! I think the best grace of wit will shortly turn into silence, and discourse grow commendable in none only but parrots. Go in, sirrah; bid them prepare for dinner. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : all of them? No wonder you look so angry!


Speaker 1 : Goodly Lord, what a wit-snapper are you! then bid them prepare dinner. 
Speaker 2 : That is done too, sir; only 'cover' is the word. 
Speaker 1 : Will you cover then, sir? 
Speaker 2 : Not so, sir, neither; I know my duty. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : thank you for coming. You will be taken care of.


Speaker 1 : Past all expressing. It is very meet The Lord Bassanio live an upright life; For, having such a blessing in his lady, He finds the joys of heaven here on earth; And if on earth he do not mean it, then In reason he should never come to heaven Why, if two gods should play some heavenly match And on the wager lay two earthly women, And Portia one, there must be something else Pawn'd with the other, for the poor rude world Hath not her fellow. 
Speaker 2 : Even such a husband Hast thou of me as she is for a wife. 
Speaker 1 : Nay, but ask my opinion too of that. 
Speaker 2 : I will anon: first, let us go to dinner. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : al right I wont interrupt you. You look so happy too.


Speaker 1 : What, is Antonio here? 
Speaker 2 : Ready, so please your grace. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : its all right your grace.


Speaker 1 : I have possess'd your grace of what I purpose; And by our holy Sabbath have I sworn To have the due and forfeit of my bond: If you deny it, let the danger light Upon your charter and your city's freedom. You'll ask me, why I rather choose to have A weight of carrion flesh than to receive Three thousand ducats: I'll not answer that: But, say, it is my humour: is it answer'd? What if my house be troubled with a rat And I be pleased to give ten thousand ducats To have it baned? What, are you answer'd yet? Some men there are love not a gaping pig; Some, that are mad if they behold a cat; And others, when the bagpipe sings i' the nose, Cannot contain their urine: for affection, Mistress of passion, sways it to the mood Of what it likes or loathes. Now, for your answer: As there is no firm reason to be render'd, Why he cannot abide a gaping pig; Why he, a harmless necessary cat; Why he, a woollen bagpipe; but of force Must yield to such inevitable shame As to offend, himself being offended; So can I give no reason, nor I will not, More than a lodged hate and a certain loathing I bear Antonio, that I follow thus A losing suit against him. Are you answer'd? 
Speaker 2 : This is no answer, thou unfeeling man, To excuse the current of thy cruelty. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand your anger. I wouldn’t want to offend you anymore. I would just like to request if you could tell me.


Speaker 1 : What judgment shall I dread, doing Were in six parts and every part a ducat, I would not draw them; I would have my bond. 
Speaker 2 : How shalt thou hope for mercy, rendering none? 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : of course you should. I am usre you will make the right call.


Speaker 1 : Not on thy sole, but on thy soul, harsh Jew, Thou makest thy knife keen; but no metal can, No, not the hangman's axe, bear half the keenness Of thy sharp envy. Can no prayers pierce thee? 
Speaker 2 : No, none that thou hast wit enough to make. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please don’t owrry so much. I am sure it will be alright soon.


Speaker 1 : I did, my lord. 
Speaker 2 : You are welcome: take your place. Are you acquainted with the difference That holds this present question in the court? 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : they are both here. Do you wish to see them?


Speaker 1 : Ay, so he says. 
Speaker 2 : Do you confess the bond? 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t be afraid then. You did a good job.


Speaker 1 : On what compulsion must I? tell me that. 
Speaker 2 : The quality of mercy is not strain'd, It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven Upon the place beneath: it is twice blest; It blesseth him that gives and him that takes: 'Tis mightiest in the mightiest: it becomes The throned monarch better than his crown; His sceptre shows the force of temporal power, The attribute to awe and majesty, Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings; But mercy is above this sceptred sway; It is enthroned in the hearts of kings, It is an attribute to God himself; And earthly power doth then show likest God's When mercy seasons justice. Therefore, Jew, Though justice be thy plea, consider this, That, in the course of justice, none of us Should see salvation: we do pray for mercy; And that same prayer doth teach us all to render The deeds of mercy. I have spoke thus much To mitigate the justice of thy plea; Which if thou follow, this strict court of Venice Must needs give sentence 'gainst the merchant there. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I can see that you are very sad about this. Could I help you in any way?


Speaker 1 : A Daniel come to judgment! yea, a Daniel! O wise young judge, how I do honour thee! 
Speaker 2 : I pray you, let me look upon the bond. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : thank you for your help


Speaker 1 : Shylock, there's thrice thy money offer'd thee. 
Speaker 2 : An oath, an oath, I have an oath in heaven: Shall I lay perjury upon my soul? No, not for Venice. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : alright. I understand your situation.


Speaker 1 : O noble judge! O excellent young man! 
Speaker 2 : For the intent and purpose of the law Hath full relation to the penalty, Which here appeareth due upon the bond. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am taking that as a compliment!


Speaker 1 : Therefore lay bare your bosom. 
Speaker 2 : Ay, his breast: So says the bond: doth it not, noble judge? 'Nearest his heart:' those are the very words. 
Speaker 1 : It is so. Are there balance here to weigh The flesh? 
Speaker 2 : I have them ready. 
Speaker 1 : Have by some surgeon, Shylock, on your charge, To stop his wounds, lest he do bleed to death. 
Speaker 2 : Is it so nominated in the bond? 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right. I should.


Speaker 1 : A pound of that same merchant's flesh is thine: The court awards it, and the law doth give it. 
Speaker 2 : Most rightful judge! 
Speaker 1 : And you must cut this flesh from off his breast: The law allows it, and the court awards it. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes yes! You look way too happy about this.


Speaker 2 : Soft! The Jew shall have all justice; soft! no haste: He shall have nothing but the penalty. 
Speaker 1 : O Jew! an upright judge, a learned judge! 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I can see this has made you sad. Is there anything I could do for you?


Speaker 2 : Shall I not have barely my principal? 
Speaker 1 : Thou shalt have nothing but the forfeiture, To be so taken at thy peril, Jew. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : alright. I understand your situation.


Speaker 2 : Ay, for the state, not for Antonio. 
Speaker 1 : Nay, take my life and all; pardon not that: You take my house when you do take the prop That doth sustain my house; you take my life When you do take the means whereby I live. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am afraid I might cause you more angry than you already are but I can only render a halter gratis; nothing else


Speaker 2 : I am content. 
Speaker 1 : Clerk, draw a deed of gift. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : alright then lets do that.


Speaker 2 : Get thee gone, but do it. 
Speaker 1 : In christening shalt thou have two god-fathers: Had I been judge, thou shouldst have had ten more, To bring thee to the gallows, not the font. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh I shall be there. It will be my pleasure.


Speaker 2 : He is well paid that is well satisfied; And I, delivering you, am satisfied And therein do account myself well paid: My mind was never yet more mercenary. I pray you, know me when we meet again: I wish you well, and so I take my leave. 
Speaker 1 : Dear sir, of force I must attempt you further: Take some remembrance of us, as a tribute, Not as a fee: grant me two things, I pray you, Not to deny me, and to pardon me. 
Speaker 2 : You press me far, and therefore I will yield. [To ANTONIO] Give me your gloves, I'll wear them for your sake; [To BASSANIO] And, for your love, I'll take this ring from you: Do not draw back your hand; I'll take no more; And you in love shall not deny me this. 
Speaker 1 : This ring, good sir, alas, it is a trifle! I will not shame myself to give you this. 
Speaker 2 : I will have nothing else but only this; And now methinks I have a mind to it. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand your anger. If there is any solution you have to this, I would love to hear it.


Speaker 1 : I see, sir, you are liberal in offers You taught me first to beg; and now methinks You teach me how a beggar should be answer'd. 
Speaker 2 : Good sir, this ring was given me by my wife; And when she put it on, she made me vow That I should neither sell nor give nor lose it. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand your anger. If there is any solution you have to this, I would love to hear it.


Speaker 1 : Inquire the Jew's house out, give him this deed And let him sign it: we'll away to-night And be a day before our husbands home: This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo. 
Speaker 2 : Fair sir, you are well o'erta'en My Lord Bassanio upon more advice Hath sent you here this ring, and doth entreat Your company at dinner. 
Speaker 1 : That cannot be: His ring I do accept most thankfully: And so, I pray you, tell him: furthermore, I pray you, show my youth old Shylock's house. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I can see you are worried about this. Would you like to talk about whats bothering you?


Speaker 2 : Sir, I would speak with you. [Aside to PORTIA] I'll see if I can get my husband's ring, Which I did make him swear to keep for ever. 
Speaker 1 : [Aside to NERISSA] Thou mayst, I warrant. We shall have old swearing That they did give the rings away to men; But we'll outface them, and outswear them too. [Aloud] Away! make haste: thou knowist where I will tarry. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes of course. I would be happy to.


Speaker 2 : The moon shines bright: in such a night as this, When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees And they did make no noise, in such a night Troilus methinks mounted the Troyan walls And sigh'd his soul toward the Grecian tents, Where Cressid lay that night. 
Speaker 2 : A friend. 
Speaker 1 : A friend! what friend? your name, I pray you, friend?

Speaker 1 : That light we see is burning in my hall. How far that little candle throws his beams! So shines a good deed in a naughty world. 
Speaker 2 : When the moon shone, we did not see the candle. 
Speaker 1 : So doth the greater glory dim the less: A substitute shines brightly as a king Unto the king be by, and then his state Empties itself, as doth an inland brook Into the main of waters. Music! hark! 
Speaker 2 : It is your music, madam, of the house. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you do look happy about it all!

Speaker 1 : We have been praying for our husbands' healths, Which speed, we hope, the better for our words. Are they return'd?

GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand. Is there anything I could do for you?


Speaker 1 : We should hold day with the Antipodes, If you would walk in absence of the sun.
