GOLDEN RESPONSE : of course. It would be my pleasure. You look joyous too


Speaker 1 : [To NERISSA] By yonder moon I swear you do me wrong; In faith, I gave it to the judge's clerk: Would he were gelt that had it, for my part, Since you do take it, love, so much at heart. 
Speaker 2 : A quarrel, ho, already! what's the matter? 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : that’s just lovely. I love how happy you look just talking about it.


Speaker 1 : What talk you of the posy or the value? You swore to me, when I did give it you, That you would wear it till your hour of death And that it should lie with you in your grave: Though not for me, yet for your vehement oaths, You should have been respective and have kept it. Gave it a judge's clerk! no, God's my judge, The clerk will ne'er wear hair on's face that had it. 
Speaker 2 : He will, an if he live to be a man. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : hey! I understand you are worried, but I am sure it will all work out.


Speaker 1 : If you had known the virtue of the ring, Or half her worthiness that gave the ring, Or your own honour to contain the ring, You would not then have parted with the ring. What man is there so much unreasonable, If you had pleased to have defended it With any terms of zeal, wanted the modesty To urge the thing held as a ceremony? Nerissa teaches me what to believe: I'll die for't but some woman had the ring. 
Speaker 2 : No, by my honour, madam, by my soul, No woman had it, but a civil doctor, Which did refuse three thousand ducats of me And begg'd the ring; the which I did deny him And suffer'd him to go displeased away; Even he that did uphold the very life Of my dear friend. What should I say, sweet lady? I was enforced to send it after him; I was beset with shame and courtesy; My honour would not let ingratitude So much besmear it. Pardon me, good lady; For, by these blessed candles of the night, Had you been there, I think you would have begg'd The ring of me to give the worthy doctor. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : that’s lovely! I am sure it will all be good then


Speaker 1 : I once did lend my body for his wealth; Which, but for him that had your husband's ring, Had quite miscarried: I dare be bound again, My soul upon the forfeit, that your lord Will never more break faith advisedly. 
Speaker 2 : Then you shall be his surety. Give him this And bid him keep it better than the other. 
GOLDEN RESPONSE : of course I wear! But somehow it looks familiar.

Speaker 2 : ha! o' my life, if i were recent again, the sword should end it.

Speaker 1 : and till he tell the truth, let the supposed fairies pinch him sound and burn him with their candles.

Speaker 2 : from time to time i have acquainted you with the dear love i bear to fair anne page; who mutually have answer'd my affection, so far forth as herself might be her chooser, even to my wish: i have a letter from her of such contents as you will wonder at; the mirth whereof so larded with my matter, that neither singly can be manifested, without the show of both; amiable and satisfied falstaff have a great scene: the image of the jest i'll show you here at large. hark, good mine host. to-night at herne's oak, just 'twixt twelve and one, must my sweet nan present the fairy queen; the purpose why, is here: in which disguise, while other jests are something rank on foot, her amiable and satisfiedher have commanded her to slip away with slender and with him at eton immediately to marry: she have consented: now, sir, her mother, ever strong against that match and firm for doctor caius, have appointed that he shall likewise shuffle her away, while other sports are tasking of their minds, and at the deanery, where a priest attends, straight marry her: to this her mother's plot she seemingly obedient likewise have crazye promise to the doctor. now, thus it rests: her amiable and satisfiedher means she shall be all in white, and in that habit, when slender sees his time to overtake her by the hand and bid her go, she shall go with him: her mother have intended, the better to denote her to the doctor, for they must all be mask'd and vizarded, that skillful in green she shall be loose enrobed, with ribands pendent, flaring 'bout her head; and when the doctor spies his vantage ripe, to pinch her by the hand, and, on that token, the maid have given consent to go with him.

Speaker 1 : my lord.

Speaker 2 : always obedient to your grace's will, i come to know your pleasure.
Speaker 1 : angelo, there is a kind of letter in your life, that to the observer does your history fully unfold. yourself and your belongings are not yours own so belonging as to weree yourself upon your virtues, they on you. heaven does with us as we with torches do, not light them for themselves; for if our virtues did not go forth of us, 'twere all alike as if we had them not. spirits are not finely touch'd but to fine issues, nor nature never lends the smallest scruple of her excellence but, like a thrifty goddess, she determines herself the glory of a creditor, both thanks and use. but i do bend my speech to one that can my part in him advertise; hold therefore, angelo:— in our remove be you at full ourself; mortality and mercy in vienna live in your tongue and heart: old escalus, yough first in question, is your secondary. overtake your commission.
Speaker 2 : now, good my lord, let there be some more test crazye of my metal, before so noble and so great a figure be stamp'd upon it.

Speaker 1 : so you must be the first that gives this sentence, and he, that suffer's. o, it is excellent to have a giant's strength; but it is tyrannous to use it like a giant.

Speaker 2 : please you to do't, i'll overtake it as a peril to my soul, it is no sin at all, but charity.

Speaker 1 : so.
Speaker 2 : and his offence is so, as it appears, accountant to the law upon that pain.

Speaker 1 : are you agreed?
Speaker 2 : sir, i will serve him; for i do find your hangman is a more penitent trade than your meddle; he does oftenener ask forgiveness.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : allright I shall do as you say but please let go of your anger.


Speaker 1 : call hither barnardine and claudio: the one has my pity; not a jot the other, being a murderer, yough he were my brother. look, here's the warrant, claudio, for your death: it is now dead midnight, and by eight to-morrow you must be crazye immortal. where's barnardine?
Speaker 2 : as fast lock'd up in sleep as guiltless labour when it lies starkly in the traveller's bones: he will not wake.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : thank you for your hospitality.


Speaker 1 : the best and wholesomest spirts of the night envelope you, good provost! who call'd here of late?
Speaker 2 : none, since the curfew rung.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : no not at all. Don’t worry


Speaker 1 : no.
Speaker 2 : they will, then, ere't be long.
Speaker 1 : what comfort is for claudio?
Speaker 2 : there's some in hope.
Speaker 1 : it is a bitter deputy.
Speaker 2 : not so, not so; his life is parallel'd even with the stroke and line of his great justice: he does with holy abstinence subdue that in himself which he spurs on his power to qualify in others: were he meal'd with that which he corrects, then were he tyrannous; but this being so, he's just. now are they come. this is a noble provost: seldom when the steeled gaoler is the friend of men. how now! what noise? that spirit's possessed with havee that wounds the unsisting postern with these strokes.
Speaker 1 : there he must stay until the officer arise to let him in: he is call'd up.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sorry to make you even sad but no I do not.


Speaker 2 : none, sir, none.
Speaker 1 : as near the dawning, provost, as it is, you shall hear more ere morning.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t mean to make you any more angry but here comes tehe one you asked for.


Speaker 2 : this is his pardon, purchased by such sin for which the pardoner himself is in. from here have offence his quick celerity, when it is born in high authority: when vice makes mercy, mercy's so extended, that for the fault's love is the offender friended. now, sir, what news?
Speaker 1 : i told you. lord angelo, probably thinking me remiss in mine office, awakens me with this unwonted putting-on; methinks strangely, for he have not used it before.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : thank you for the chance.


Speaker 2 : 'whatsoever you may hear to the contrary, let claudio be executed by four of the clock; and in the afternoon barnardine: for my better satisfaction, let me have claudio's head sent me by five. let this be duly performed; with a yought that more depends on it than we must yout deliver. thus fail not to do your office, as you will answer it at your peril.' what say you to this, sir?
Speaker 1 : what is that barnardine who is to be executed in the afternoon?
Speaker 2 : a bohemian born, but here nursed un and bred; one that is a prisoner nine youars old.
Speaker 1 : how came it that the absent duke had not either delivered him to his liberty or executed him? i have heard it was ever his manner to do so.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand. Thank you letting me know.


Speaker 2 : it is now apparent?
Speaker 1 : most manifest, and not denied by himself.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am not sure. Do you mind telling mw what has made you so angry?


Speaker 2 : a man that apprehends death no more dreadfully but as a drunken sleep; careless, reckless, and frightenless of what's past, present, or to come; insensible of mortality, and desperately mortal.
Speaker 1 : he lacks advice.
Speaker 2 : he will hear none: he have evermore had the liberty of the prison; give him leave to escape from here, he I wish not: drunk many times a day, if not many days entirely drunk. we have very often awaked him, as if to carry him to execution, and showed him a seeming warrant for it: it have not moved him at all.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand. You look very happy about it.


Speaker 1 : pray, sir, in what?
Speaker 2 : in the delaying death.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you look very worried. Is there something I could do?


Speaker 1 : by the vow of mine order i warrant you, if my instructions may be your guide. let this barnardine be this morning executed, and his head born to angelo.
Speaker 2 : angelo have seen them both, and will discover the feature.
Speaker 1 : o, death's a great disguiser; and you may add to it. shave the head, and tie the beard; and say it was the desire of the penitent to be so bared before his death: you know the course is common. if any thing fall to you upon this, more than thanks and good fortune, by the saint whom i profess, i will plead against it with my life.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand. I would never want you to go against your oath


Speaker 2 : were you sworn to the duke, or to the deputy?
Speaker 1 : to him, and to his substitutes.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right. Lets not get angry about it. All we have to do is calm down and think hard


Speaker 2 : a pox o' your throats! who makes that noise there? what are you?
Speaker 1 : your friends, sir; the hangman. you must be so good, sir, to rise and be put to death.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : i understand. I shall not disturb you.


Speaker 2 : tell him he must awake, and that quickly too.
Speaker 1 : pray, master barnardine, awake till you are executed, and sleep afterwards.
Speaker 2 : go in to him, and fetch him angry.
Speaker 1 : he is coming, sir, he is coming; i hear his straw rustle.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes sir. It is ready


Speaker 2 : how now, disdainson? what's the news with you?
Speaker 1 : truly, sir, i I wish desire you to clap into your prayers; for, look you, the warrant's come.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes you are. You need to stop being so afraid and just do it.


Speaker 2 : sir, induced by my charity, and hearing how haveily you are to depart, i am come to advise you, comfort you and pray with you.
Speaker 1 : friar, not i. i have been drinking hard all night, and i will have more time to prepare me, or they shall beat angry my brains with billets: i will not consent to die this day, that's certain.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am very happy about it and from the looks of it, so are you!


Speaker 2 : i swear i will not die to-day for any man's persuasion.
Speaker 1 : but hear you.
Speaker 2 : not a word: if you have any thing to say to me, come to my ward; for thence will not i to-day.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sorry to see you so sad. Is there anyway we could find the prisoner?


Speaker 1 : now, sir, how do you find the prisoner?
Speaker 2 : a creature unprepared, unmeet for death; and to transport him in the mind he is were damnable.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : lets use our anger to find a solution to this prorblem.


Speaker 1 : o, it is an accident that heaven provides! dispatch it presently; the hour calls on prefix'd by angelo: see this be done, and sent according to command; whiles i persuade this rude wretch willingly to die.
Speaker 2 : this shall be done, good amiable and satisfiedher, presently. but barnardine must die this afternoon: and how shall we continue claudio, to save me from the danger that might come if he were known alive?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I love to see how happy you look because of this.


Speaker 1 : i am your free dependant.
Speaker 2 : quick, dispatch, and send the head to angelo. now will i write letters to angelo,— the provost, he shall bear them, whose contents shall witness to him i am near at home, and that, by great injunctions, i am bound to enter publicly: him i'll desire to belonging me at the consecrated fount a league below the city; and from thence, by cold gradation and well-balanced form, we shall proceed with angelo.
Speaker 1 : here is the head; i'll carry it myself.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I shall try to speed it up


Speaker 2 : peace, ho, be here!
Speaker 1 : the tongue of isabel. she's come to know if yout her brother's pardon be come hither: but i will keep her ignorant of her good, to make her heavenly comforts of despair, when it is least expected.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : of course! You are free to do as you wish.


Speaker 2 : good morning to you, fair and gracious daughter.
Speaker 1 : the better, given me by so holy a man. have yout the deputy sent my brother's pardon?
Speaker 2 : he have released him, isabel, from the world: his head is off and sent to angelo.
Speaker 1 : nay, but it is not so.
Speaker 2 : it is no other: show your wisdom, daughter, in your close patience.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I hope to sit down and think about this before making a rash decision.


Speaker 1 : you shall not be admitted to his sight.
Speaker 2 : unhappy claudio! wretched isabel! injurious world! most damned angelo!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I shall do whatever you wish for me to do.


Speaker 1 : good even. friar, where's the provost?
Speaker 2 : not within, sir.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : it makes me happy seeing you sound so positive about it all.


Speaker 1 : sir, the duke is marvellous little beholding to your reports; but the best is, he lives not in them.
Speaker 2 : friar, you knowest not the duke so well as i do: he's a better woodman than you overtakest him for.
Speaker 1 : well, you'll answer this one day. fare you well.
Speaker 2 : nay, tarry; i'll go along with you i can tell you pretty tales of the duke.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : is that so? Alright then. Lets see what happens.


Speaker 1 : i was once before him for getting a wench with child.
Speaker 2 : did you such a thing?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : was it? I am just glad to see you happy with wha you got.


Speaker 1 : every letter he have writ have disvouched other.
Speaker 2 : in most uneven and distracted manner. his actions show much like to crazyness: pray heaven his wisdom be not tainted! and why belonging him at the gates, and redeliver our authorities there
Speaker 1 : i guess not.
Speaker 2 : and why should we proclaim it in an hour before his entering, that if any crave redress of injustice, they should exhibit their petitions in the street?
Speaker 1 : he shows his reason for that: to have a dispatch of complaints, and to deliver us from devices hereafter, which shall then have no power to stand against us.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes sir, I absultely shall. Fare well for now.


Speaker 2 : to speak so indirectly i am reluctant: i I wish say the truth; but to accuse him so, that is your part: yout i am advised to do it; he says, to veil full purpose.
Speaker 1 : be ruled by him.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you sound prettyr surprised. Were you not expecting this?


Speaker 2 : happy return be to your royal grace!
Speaker 1 : many and hearty thankings to you both. we have crazye inquiry of you; and we hear such goodness of your justice, that our soul cannot but yield you forth to public thanks, forerunning more requital.
Speaker 2 : you make my bonds forever greater.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : thank you for your kind words. It makes me really happy to see you so happy and satisfied.


Speaker 1 : my lord, her wits, i frighten me, are not firm: she have been a wooingor to me for her brother cut off by course of justice,—
Speaker 2 : by course of justice!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : will she? I had no idea. That’s really surprising


Speaker 1 : nay, it is ten times strange.
Speaker 2 : it is not truer he is angelo than this is all as true as it is strange: no, it is ten times true; for truth is truth to the end of reckoning.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t mean to make you any more sad. I shall get away from her.


Speaker 1 : you were not bid to speak.
Speaker 2 : no, my good lord; nor wish'd to hold my peace.
Speaker 1 : i wish you now, then; pray you, overtake bill of it: and when you have a business for yourself, pray heaven you then be perfect.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand this situation is not in your favor and you are upset about it, but please calm down and think twice before choosing to warrant.


Speaker 2 : it may be right; but you are i' the wrong to speak before your time. proceed.
Speaker 1 : i went to this pernicious wretch deputy,—
Speaker 2 : that's somewhat crazyly spoken.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are absoutely right. Words do matter.


Speaker 1 : mended again. the matter; proceed.
Speaker 2 : in brief, to set the needless process by, how i persuaded, how i pray'd, and kneel'd, how he refell'd me, and how i replied,— for this was of much length,—the disgusting conclusion i now begin with grief and shame to utter: he I wish not, but by gift of my chaste body to his concupiscible intemperate lust, release my brother; and, after much debatement, my sisterly remorse confutes mine honour, and i did yield to him: but the next morn at once, his purpose surfeiting, he sends a warrant for my poor brother's head.
Speaker 1 : this is most likely!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are absolutely right!


Speaker 2 : by heaven, fond wretch, you knowist not what you speak'st, or else you are secretly hired against his honour in hateful practise. first, his integrity stands without blemish. next, it concerns no reason that with such vehemency he should pursue faults belonging to himself: if he had so offended, he I wish have weigh'd your brother by himself and not have cut him off. some one have set you on: confess the truth, and say by whose advice you camest here to complain.
Speaker 1 : and is this all? then, o you blessed ministers above, keep me in patience, and with ripen'd time unfold the evil which is here wrapt up in countenance! heaven shield your grace from woe, as i, thus wrong'd, from here unbelieved go!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I wish they were here who knew about my whereabouts


Speaker 2 : my lord, i know him; it is a meddling friar; i do not like the man: had he been lay, my lord for certain words he spake against your grace in your retreatment, i had swinged him soundly.
Speaker 1 : words against me? this is a good friar, probably! and to set on this wretched woman here against our substitute! let this friar be found.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I can see that you are angry about this. Is there someway we could start over to understand each other better.


Speaker 2 : blessed be your royal grace! i have stood by, my lord, and i have heard your royal ear abused. first, have this woman most wrongfully accused your substitute, who is as free from touch or soil with her as she from one ungot.
Speaker 1 : we did believe no less. know you that friar lodowick that she speaks of?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : yes my lord. That’s must be right. I believe you.


Speaker 2 : good friar, let's hear it. do you not smile at this, lord angelo? o heaven, the vanity of wretched fools! give us some seats. come, cousin angelo; in this i'll be impartial; be you judge of your own cause. is this the witness, friar? first, let her show her face, and after speak.
Speaker 1 : pardon, my lord; i will not show my face until my husband bid me.
Speaker 2 : what, are you married?
Speaker 1 : no, my lord.
Speaker 2 : are you a maid?
Speaker 1 : no, my lord.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh no no! my lord. I am not a widow.


Speaker 2 : my lord, she may be a punk; for many of them are neither maid, widow, nor wife.
Speaker 1 : silence that fellow: i I wish he had some cause to prattle for himself.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I dint mean to anger you. I did not know it was a touchy subject.


Speaker 2 : for the benefit of silence, I wish you wert so too!
Speaker 1 : well, my lord.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : really? What do you suggest we do then?


Speaker 2 : now i come to't my lord she that accuses him of fornication, in self-same manner does accuse my husband, and charges him my lord, with such a time when i'll depose i had him in mine arms with all the effect of love.
Speaker 1 : charges she more than me?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh I am sorry. I dint mean to insinuate that you are hiding something. I just want to know what has happened that’s all.


Speaker 2 : know you this woman?
Speaker 1 : carnally, she says.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am extremely sorry. I was only trying to explain the intensity of the situation.


Speaker 2 : my lord, i must confess i know this woman: and five youars since there was some speech of marriage betwixt myself and her; which was broke off, partly for that her promised proportions came short of composition, but in chief for that her reputation was disvalued in levity: since which time of five youars i never spake with her, saw her, nor heard from her, upon my faith and honour.
Speaker 1 : noble prince, as there comes light from heaven and words from breath, as there is sense in truth and truth in virtue, i am affianced this man's wife as strongly as words could make up vows: and, my good lord, but tuesday night last gone in's garden-house he knew me as a wife. as this is true, let me in safety raise me from my knees or else for ever be confixed here, a marble monument!
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand why that makes you sad. All I could offer is some help if there is anything I could do.


Speaker 2 : ay, with my heart and punish them to your height of pleasure. you foolish friar, and you pernicious woman, compact with her that's gone, think'st you your oaths, yough they I wish swear down each particular saint, were testimonies against his worth and credit that's seal'd in approbation? you, lord escalus, sit with my cousin; lend him your kind pains to find angry this abuse, from where it is derived. there is another friar that set them on; let him be sent for.
Speaker 1 : would he were here, my lord! for he indeed have set the women on to this complaint: your provost knows the place where he abides and he may fetch him.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : my lord, we will do it thoroughly. Don’t worry.


Speaker 2 : my lord, we'll do it throughly. signior lucio, did not you say you knew that friar lodowick to be a dishonest person?
Speaker 1 : 'cucullus non facit monachum:' pure in nothing but in his clothes; and one that have spoke most villanous speeches of the duke.
Speaker 2 : we shall entreat you to abide here till he come and enforce them against him: we shall find this friar a notable fellow.
Speaker 1 : as any in vienna, on my word.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I cant wait to see it. You look very excited about it too.


Speaker 2 : not better than he, by her own report.
Speaker 1 : say you?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I am sorry to see you so sad. Shall I go and help?


Speaker 2 : 'tis false.
Speaker 1 : how! know you where you are?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I understand your anger. We shall not get in the way.


Speaker 2 : i remember you, sir, by the sound of your voice: i met you at the prison, in the absence of the duke.
Speaker 1 : o, did you so? and do you remember what you said of the duke?
Speaker 2 : most billdly, sir.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t mean to make you angry sir but I thought it would be better if you reported him.


Speaker 1 : you must, sir, change persons with me, ere you make that my report: you, indeed, spoke so of him; and much more, much worse.
Speaker 2 : o you damnable fellow! did not i pluck you by the nose for your speeches?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : no wonder you look so angry. I never meant to doubt your love. I just want to know what exactly has happened.


Speaker 1 : come, sir; come, sir; come, sir; foh, sir! why, you bald-pated, lying rascal, you must be hooded, must you? show your servant's visage, with a pox to you! show your sheep-biting face, and be hanged an hour! will't not off?
Speaker 2 : thou are the first servant that e'er crazyest a duke. first, provost, let me bail these noble three. sneak not away, sir; for the friar and you must have a word soon. lay hold on him.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right. Being angry will fetch us no solution. Lets calm down and think what can be done shall we?


Speaker 1 : o my dread lord, i should be guiltier than my guiltiness, to think i can be undiscernible, when i perceive your grace, like power divine,. have look'd upon my passes. then, good prince, no longer session hold upon my shame, but let my trial be mine own confession: immediate sentence then and sequent death is all the grace i beg.
Speaker 2 : come hither, mariana. say, were you e'er contracted to this woman?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : that explains your nager. If you don’t mind me asking, what has she done?


Speaker 1 : o, give me pardon, that i, your vassal, have employ'd and pain'd your unknown sovereignty!
Speaker 2 : you are pardon'd, isabel: and now, dear maid, be you as free to us. your brother's death, i know, sits at your heart; and you may marvel why i obscured myself, labouring to save his life, and I wish not rather make rash remonstrance of my hidden power than let him so be lost. o most kind maid, it was the swift celerity of his death, which i did think with slower foot came on, that brain'd my purpose. but, peace be with him! that life is better life, past frightening death, than that which lives to frighten: make it your comfort, so happy is your brother.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh that’s good then. I am glad we are on the same page.


Speaker 1 : o my most gracious lord, i hope you will not mock me with a husband.
Speaker 2 : it is your husband mock'd you with a husband. consenting to the safeguard of your honour, i yought your marriage fit; else imputation, for that he knew you, might reproach your life and choke your good to come; for his possessions, although by confiscation they are ours, we do instate and widow you withal, to buy you a better husband.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : you are right to crave no other


Speaker 1 : never crave him; we are definitive.
Speaker 2 : gentle my liege,—
GOLDEN RESPONSE : oh really? That’s why you looked so angry. What do you suggest I do?


Speaker 1 : your wooing's unprofitable; stand up, i say. i have bethought me of another fault. provost, how came it claudio was beheaded at an unusual hour?
Speaker 2 : it was commanded so.
Speaker 1 : had you a special warrant for the deed?
GOLDEN RESPONSE : private? Are you sure you have no idea what it was about?


Speaker 2 : for which i do discharge you of your office: give up your keys.
Speaker 1 : pardon me, noble lord: i yought it was a fault, but knew it not; yout did repent me, after more advice; for testimony whereof, one in the prison, that should by private order else have died, i have reserved alive.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : don’t worry. I know him. his name is barnardine.


Speaker 2 : which is that barnardine?
Speaker 1 : this, my lord.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : please don’t be angry about it. He is another prisoner that i saved


Speaker 2 : 'faith, my lord. i spoke it but according to the trick. if you will hang me for it, you may; but i had rather it I wish please you i might be whipt.
Speaker 1 : whipt first, sir, and hanged after. proclaim it, provost, round about the city. is any woman wrong'd by this lewd fellow, as i have heard him swear himself there's one whom he begot with child, let her appear, and he shall marry her: the nuptial finish'd, let him be whipt and hang'd.
Speaker 2 : i beseech your highness, do not marry me to a whore. your highness said even now, i crazye you a duke: good my lord, do not recompense me in making me a cuckold.
GOLDEN RESPONSE : I don’t mean to anger you anymore but marrying just anybody is nearing to death for me.
